revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} On 26 September 1983, the nuclear [[Early warning radar|early-warning system]] of the [[Soviet Union]] reported the launch of multiple [[U.S. Air Force|USAF]] [[LGM-30 Minuteman|Minuteman]] [[intercontinental ballistic missile]]s from bases in the [[United States]]. These missile attack warnings were correctly identified as a [[false alarm]] by [[Stanislav Petrov|Stanislav Yevgrafovich Petrov]], an officer of the [[Soviet Air Defence Forces]]. This decision is seen as having prevented a retaliatory nuclear attack based on erroneous data on the United States and its [[NATO]] allies, which would have probably resulted in immediate escalation of the [[cold-war]] [[mutually assured destruction|stalemate]] to a full-scale [[nuclear war]]. Investigation of the satellite warning system later confirmed that the system had malfunctioned. ==Background== The incident occurred at a time of severely strained relations between the [[United States]] and the [[Soviet Union]].{{cite news | title=Soviet officer who averted nuclear war dies | date=20 September 2017 | agency=Associated Press }} Responding to the Soviet Union's deployment of [[SS-20 Saber#Deployment|14]] [[RSD-10 Pioneer|SS-20/RSD-10]] theatre nuclear missiles, the [[NATO Double-Track Decision]] was taken in December 1979 by the military commander of NATO to deploy 108 [[Pershing II]] nuclear missiles in Western Europe with the ability to hit targets in eastern [[Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic|Ukraine]], [[Byelorussian Soviet Socialist Republic|Belarus]] or [[Lithuanian Soviet Socialist Republic|Lithuania]] within 10 minutes and the longer range, but slower [[BGM-109G Ground Launched Cruise Missile]] (GLCM) to strike potential targets farther to the east. In mid-February 1981, and continuing until 1983, [[Able Archer 83#PSYOP|psychological operations]] by the United States began. These were designed to test Soviet radar vulnerability and to demonstrate US nuclear capabilities. They included clandestine naval operations, in the Barents, Norwegian, Black, and Baltic seas and near the Greenland-Iceland-United Kingdom (GIUK) gap, as well as flights by American bombers, occasionally several times per week, directly to Soviet airspace that turned away only at the last moment.Peter Schweizer, ''Victory: The Reagan Administration's Secret Strategy That Hastened the Collapse of the Soviet Union'' (New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press, 1994), p. 8, as quoted at Fischer, "A Cold War Conundrum" (CIA Centre for the Study of Intelligence, 2007)[https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/books-and-monographs/a-cold-war-conundrum/source.htm#HEADING1-07]. Retrieved on 18 May 2013.
"It really got to them," recalls Dr. [[William Schneider, Jr.|William Schneider]], [former] [[United States Department of State#Organization|undersecretary of state]] for military assistance and technology, who saw classified "after-action reports" that indicated U.S. flight activity. "They didn't know what it all meant. A squadron would fly straight at Soviet airspace, and other radars would light up and units would go on alert. Then at the last minute the squadron would peel off and return home."Peter Schweizer, ''Victory: The Reagan Administration's Secret Strategy That Hastened the Collapse of the Soviet Union'' (New York: The Atlantic Monthly Press, 1994), p. 8, as quoted at Fischer, "A Cold War Conundrum" (CIA Centre for the Study of Intelligence, 2007)[https://www.cia.gov/library/center-for-the-study-of-intelligence/csi-publications/books-and-monographs/a-cold-war-conundrum/source.htm#HEADING1-07].
From the accounts of CIA and [[Oleg Gordievsky|senior KGB officers]]Andrew and Gordievsky, ''Comrade Kryuchkov's Instructions: Top Secret Files on KGB Foreign Operations, 1975–1985'', 74–6, 86, Stanford UP 1993 https://books.google.com/books?id=6ahujvo6ukwC {{ISBN|0-8047-2228-5}} ,{{cite web|url=http://www2.gwu.edu/~nsarchiv/NSAEBB/NSAEBB426/docs/3.The%201983%20War%20Scare%20in%20U.S.%20Soviet%20Relations-circa%201996.pdf|title=The 1983 War Scare in US-Soviet Relations|first=Ben B.|last=Fischer|publisher=National Security Archive|accessdate=21 November 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150328151950/http://nsarchive.gwu.edu/NSAEBB/NSAEBB426/docs/3.The%201983%20War%20Scare%20in%20U.S.%20Soviet%20Relations-circa%201996.pdf|archivedate=28 March 2015|deadurl=no}} by May 1981, obsessed with historical parallels with 1941 and [[Evil Empire speech|Reaganite rhetoric]], and with no defensive capability against the Pershing IIs, Soviet leaders believed the United States was preparing a secret nuclear attack on the USSR and initiated [[Operation RYaN]]. Under this, agents abroad monitored service and technical personnel who would implement a nuclear attack so as to be able either to preempt it or have [[Mutual assured destruction|mutually assured destruction]]. On 1 September 1983, the Soviet military shot down a South Korean passenger jet, [[Korean Air Lines Flight 007]], that had strayed into Soviet [[airspace]]. All 269 people aboard the aircraft were killed,{{cite news |url= http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war/episodes/22/spotlight/ |title= War Games: Soviets, Fearing Western Attack, Prepared for Worst in '83 |publisher= [[CNN]] |first= Bruce |last= Kennedy |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20081219114101/http://www.cnn.com/SPECIALS/cold.war/episodes/22/spotlight/ |archivedate= 19 December 2008 }} including [[United States Congress|U.S. Congressman]] [[Larry McDonald]] and many other Americans.{{cite journal |last= Oberg |first= James |title= KAL 007: The Real Story |journal= American Spectator |volume= 26 |issue= 10 |year= 1993 |page= 37|url=http://www.unz.org/Pub/AmSpectator-1993oct-00037 |via=[[UNZ.org]]|access-date= 22 July 2017 }} The first Pershing II missiles were reportedly deployed in late November 1983. Bruce Blair, an expert on [[Cold War]] nuclear strategies and former president of the [[World Security Institute]] in [[Washington, D.C.]], says the American–Soviet relationship at that time
had deteriorated to the point where the Soviet Union as a system—not just the Kremlin, not just Soviet leader [[Yuri Andropov]], not just the KGB—but as a system, was geared to expect an attack and to retaliate very quickly to it. It was on hair-trigger alert. It was very nervous and prone to mistakes and accidents. The false alarm that happened on Petrov's watch could not have come at a more dangerous, intense phase in U.S.–Soviet relations.{{cite web |url= http://www.logtv.com/films/redbutton/video.htm |title= The Red Button & the Man Who Saved the World |publisher= logtv.com |accessdate= 27 September 2006 |format= Flash |first= Ewa |last= Pieta |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20061016184311/http://www.logtv.com/films/redbutton/video.htm |archivedate= 16 October 2006 |deadurl= yes |df= dmy-all }}
In an interview aired on American television, Blair said, "The Russians (Soviets) saw a U.S. government preparing for a first strike, headed by a President [[Ronald Reagan]] capable of ordering a first strike." Regarding the incident involving Petrov, he said, "I think that this is the closest our country has come to accidental nuclear war."{{cite news |title= War Games |publisher= Burrelle's Information Services |work= Dateline NBC |date= 12 November 2000}} == Incident == On 26 September 1983, [[Stanislav Petrov]], a lieutenant colonel in the [[Soviet Air Defence Forces|Soviet Air Defense Forces]], was the officer on duty at the [[Serpukhov-15]] bunker near [[Moscow]] which housed the command center of the Soviet [[early warning]] satellites, code-named [[Oko]].[http://www.flb.ru/info/27637.html Дайджест : Тот, который не нажал] Petrov's responsibilities included observing the satellite early warning network and notifying his superiors of any impending nuclear missile attack against the Soviet Union. If notification was received from the early warning systems that inbound missiles had been detected, the Soviet Union's strategy was an immediate and compulsory nuclear counter-attack against the [[United States]] ([[launch on warning]]), specified in the doctrine of [[mutual assured destruction]]. Shortly after midnight, the bunker's computers reported that one [[intercontinental ballistic missile]] was heading toward the Soviet Union from the United States. Petrov considered the detection a computer error, since a first-strike nuclear attack by the United States was likely to involve hundreds of simultaneous missile launches in order to disable any Soviet means of a counterattack. Furthermore, the satellite system's reliability had been questioned in the past.{{cite news |url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/inatl/longterm/coldwar/shatter021099b.htm |title= I Had A Funny Feeling in My Gut |first= David |last= Hoffman |work= Washington Post |date= 10 February 1999 |accessdate= 18 April 2006 }} Petrov dismissed the warning as a [[false alarm]], though accounts of the event differ as to whether he notified his superiors{{cite web|url=http://www.worldcitizens.org/petrov2.html|title=The Man Who Saved the World Finally Recognized|publisher=Association of World Citizens|accessdate=7 June 2007|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721000030/http://www.worldcitizens.org/petrov2.html|archive-date=21 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} or not{{full citation needed|date=November 2012}} after he concluded that the computer detections were false and that no missile had been launched. Petrov's suspicion that the warning system was malfunctioning was confirmed when no missile in fact arrived. Later, the computers identified four additional missiles in the air, all directed towards the Soviet Union. Petrov suspected that the computer system was malfunctioning again, despite having no direct means to confirm this.{{cite av media |title=Able Archer 1983 The Brink of Apocalypse |publisher=Channel 4 |time=29:06 mins |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7ciy5R-tLiE}} The Soviet Union's land [[radar]] was incapable of detecting missiles beyond the horizon. It was subsequently determined that the false alarms were caused by a rare alignment of sunlight on high-altitude clouds and the satellites' [[Molniya orbit]]s,{{Cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/09/18/stanislav-petrov-the-man-who-quietly-saved-the-world-has-died-aged-77-6937015/|title=Stanislav Petrov - the man who quietly saved the world - has died aged 77|date=18 September 2017|work=Metro|access-date=19 September 2017|language=en-GB}} an error later corrected by cross-referencing a geostationary satellite.[http://www.everything2.com/index.pl?node=Molniya%20orbit Molniya orbit] In explaining the factors leading to his decision, Petrov cited his belief and training that any U.S. first strike would be massive, so five missiles seemed an illogical start. In addition, the launch detection system was new and in his view not yet wholly trustworthy, while ground radar had failed to pick up corroborative evidence even after several minutes of the false alarm. == Aftermath == Petrov underwent intense questioning by his superiors about his actions. Initially, he was praised for his decision. General [[Yury Votintsev]], then commander of the Soviet Air Defense's Missile Defense Units, who was the first to hear Petrov's report of the incident (and the first to reveal it to the public in the 1990s), stated that Petrov's "correct actions" were "duly noted." Petrov himself stated he was initially praised by Votintsev and was promised a reward,[http://www.flb.ru/info/27637.html Тот, который не нажал]. [[Moskovskiye Novosti]] (in Russian) but recalled that he was also reprimanded for improper filing of paperwork with the pretext that he had not described the incident in the military diary.BBC TV Interview, BBC Moscow correspondent Allan Little, October 1998 He received no reward. According to Petrov, this was because the incident and other bugs found in the missile detection system embarrassed his superiors and the influential scientists who were responsible for it, so that if he had been officially rewarded, they would have had to be punished.[http://lenta.ru/news/2006/01/20/petrov/ В Нью-Йорке россиянина наградили за спасение мира]. Lenta.ru (in Russian) He was reassigned to a less sensitive post, took early retirement (although he emphasized that he was not "forced out" of the army, as is sometimes claimed by Western sources), and suffered a [[nervous breakdown]]. [[Oleg Kalugin]], a former KGB chief of foreign counter-intelligence who knew Soviet chairman Andropov well, says that Andropov's distrust of American leaders was profound. It is conceivable that if Petrov had declared the satellite warnings valid, such an erroneous report could have provoked the Soviet leadership into becoming bellicose. Kalugin said, "The danger was in the Soviet leadership thinking, 'The Americans may attack, so we better attack first.'"{{cite news |title= Cold War's Riskiest Moment |work= Baltimore Sun |date= 31 August 2003 |url= http://hnn.us/articles/1709.html#bombs9-5-03 |first= Scott |last= Shane |accessdate= 20 August 2006 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060819033034/http://hnn.us/articles/1709.html |archivedate= 19 August 2006 |deadurl= yes}} (article reprinted as "The Nuclear War That Almost Happened in 1983"') The incident became known publicly in the 1990s upon the publication of Votintsev's memoirs. Widespread media reports since then have increased public awareness of Petrov's actions.{{cn|date=April 2018}} == See also == {{Portalbar|Soviet Union|Cold War|1980s|International relations}} * [[Able Archer 83]] – NATO military exercise that happened over a month after the Petrov incident * ''[[Deutschland 83]]'' * [[List of nuclear close calls]] * [[2018 Hawaii false missile alert]] – a similar incident where a false ballistic missile alert was issued in the U.S. State of Hawaii * [[Norwegian rocket incident]] – a rocket carrying scientific equipment to study the aurora borealis resembled a submarine-launched Trident missile * [[Vasili Arkhipov]] – another nuclear war-averting incident during the Cuban Missile Crisis * ''[[WarGames]]'' – a 1983 movie released four months prior to the incident, depicting an early warning system's false alarm of a thermonuclear strike * [[World War III#Historical close calls|World War III]] – Situations resulting in close encounters of a third world war * [[1961 Goldsboro B-52 crash]] – another nuclear accident which narrowly missed widespread destruction == References == {{reflist|30em}} == External links == * [http://www.brightstarsound.com BrightStarSound.com] Stanislav Petrov tribute website, multiple pages with photos and reprints of various articles about Petrov * [http://www.brightstarsound.com/world_hero/weekendavisen.html Nuclear War: Minuteman] Article from ''Weekendavisen'', 2 April 2004. * [http://hnn.us/articles/1709.html#bombs9-5-03 The Nuclear War that Almost Happened in 1983 (posted September 5, 2003)]. ''History News Network'', Originally in the ''Baltimore Sun'' of 31 August 2003 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040626091513/http://www.cdi.org/russia/308-12.cfm Armageddon Almost Not Averted] ''link is dead on 30 September 2013'' * [https://www.wired.com/science/discoveries/news/2007/09/dayintech_0926 "Sept. 26, 1983: The Man Who Saved the World by Doing ... Nothing"]. * [https://www.theregister.co.uk/2013/09/27/30_years_on_the_day_a_computer_glitch_nearly_caused_world_war_iii/ 30 years on: The day a computer glitch nearly caused World War III]. ''The Register''. 27 September 2013 {{Stagnation Era}} [[Category:Cold War military history of the Soviet Union]] [[Category:1983 in the Soviet Union]] [[Category:Soviet Union–United States relations]] [[Category:Early warning systems]] [[Category:Nuclear command and control]] [[Category:Computer errors]] [[Category:1983 controversies]] [[Category:September 1983 events]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox NCAA Basketball Tournament | | Year=2020 | Season= 2019–20 | Image= <!-- 2020 NCAA Men's Final Four logo.svg --> | ImageSize= | Caption= | Teams=68 | FinalFourArena=[[Mercedes-Benz Stadium]] | FinalFourCity=[[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]] | Champions= | TitleCount= | RunnerUp= | GameCount= | Semifinal1= | FinalFourCount= | Semifinal2= | FinalFourCount2= | Coach= | CoachCount= | MOP= | MOPTeam= | Attendance= | OneTopScorer= | TwoTopScorers= | TopScorer= | TopScorerTeam= | TopScorer2= | TopScorer2Team= | Points= }}
The '''2020 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament''' will be a 68-team [[single-elimination tournament]] to determine the men's [[NCAA|National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] [[college basketball]] national champion for the <!-- [[2019–20 NCAA Division I men's basketball season|]] -->2019–20 season. The 82nd edition of the [[NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament|Tournament]] is scheduled to begin on March 17, 2020 and will conclude with the championship game on April 6 at [[Mercedes-Benz Stadium]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia]].
==Tournament procedure== {{details|NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Championship#Tournament format}}
Pending any changes to the current format, a total of 68 teams will enter the 2020 tournament. 32 automatic bids shall be awarded to each program that wins their [[List of NCAA conferences|conference's]] tournament. The remaining 36 bids are "at-large", with selections extended by the NCAA Selection Committee.
Eight teams (the four lowest-seeded automatic qualifiers and the four lowest-seeded at-large teams) will play in the First Four (the successor to what had been popularly known as "[[NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Opening Round game|play-in games]]" through the 2010 tournament). The winners of these games advance to the main draw of the tournament.
The [[NCAA basketball tournament selection process|Selection Committee]] will also seed the entire field from 1 to 68. ==2020 NCAA Tournament schedule and venues== {{Location map+|USA|width=450|float=right|caption=2020 First Four (orange) and first and second rounds (green)|places= {{Location map~|USA|mark=orange pog.svg|lat_deg=39.7404|lon_deg=-84.1792|position=left|background=#FFFFFF|label=Dayton|link=University Of Dayton Arena}} }} The following are the sites selected to host each round of the 2020 tournament:<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ncaa.org/championships/future-division-i-mens-basketball-championship-sites|date=21 April 2017|publisher=[[NCAA]]|title=Future Division I Men's Basketball Championship sites}}</ref>
'''First Four''' *March 17 and 18 **[[UD Arena|University of Dayton Arena]], [[Dayton, Ohio]] (Host: [[University of Dayton]])
'''First and Second Rounds''' *March 19 and 21 ** [[Times Union Center]], [[Albany, New York]] (Host: [[Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference]]) ** [[Spokane Veterans Memorial Arena]], [[Spokane, Washington]] (Host: [[University of Idaho]]) ** [[Enterprise Center]], [[St. Louis, Missouri]] (Host: [[Missouri Valley Conference]]) ** [[Amalie Arena]], [[Tampa, Florida]] (Host: [[University of South Florida]])
*March 20 and 22 ** [[Greensboro Coliseum]], [[Greensboro, North Carolina]] (Host: [[Atlantic Coast Conference]]) ** [[CHI Health Center Omaha]], [[Omaha, Nebraska]] (Host: [[Creighton University]]) ** [[Golden 1 Center]], [[Sacramento, California]] (Host: [[Sacramento State University]]) ** [[Quicken Loans Arena]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] (Host: [[Mid-American Conference]]/[[Cleveland State University]])
'''Regional Semifinals and Finals''' (Sweet Sixteen and Elite Eight) *March 26 and 28 **'''Midwest Regional''', [[Lucas Oil Stadium]], [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] (Host: [[Horizon League]]/[[IUPUI]]) **'''West Regional''', [[Staples Center]], [[Los Angeles, California]] (Host: [[Pepperdine University]])
*March 27 and 29 **'''South Regional''', [[Toyota Center]], [[Houston, Texas]] (Host: [[University of Houston]]/[[Rice University]]/[[Texas Southern University]]) **'''East Regional''', [[Madison Square Garden]], [[New York, New York]] (Host: [[St. John's University (New York City)|St. John’s University]]/[[Big East Conference]])
'''National Semifinals and Championship''' (Final Four and Championship) *April 4 and 6 **[[Mercedes-Benz Stadium]], [[Atlanta, Georgia]] (Host: [[Georgia Institute of Technology]])
==Media Coverage== ===Television=== [[CBS Sports]] and [[Turner Sports]] have US television rights to the tournament. *First Four – [[truTV]] *First and Second rounds – [[CBS]], [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]], [[TNT (U.S. TV network)|TNT]], truTV *Regional Semifinals and Finals (Sweet Sixteen and Elite Eight) – CBS and TBS *National Semifinals (Final Four) – TBS *National Championship – TBS <!--====Studio hosts====
====Studio analysts====
====Commentary teams====-->
===Radio=== [[Westwood One (current)|Westwood One]] has exclusive radio rights to the entire tournament. <!--{{col-begin}} {{col-2}}
====First Four====
====First and Second rounds====
{{col-2}}
====Regionals====
====Final four====
{{col-end}}--> ===Internet=== ====Video==== Live video of games will be available for streaming through the following means:<ref name="2017 TV">{{cite web|last1=Maiman|first1=Beth|title=March Madness TV schedule: How to watch and live stream every game in the NCAA men's basketball tournament|url=https://www.ncaa.com/news/basketball-men/article/march-madness-2017-tv-schedule-how-watch-and-live-stream|publisher=NCAA|accessdate=March 9, 2017|date=March 8, 2017}}</ref> * NCAA March Madness Live (website and app, no CBS games on [[digital media player]]s; access to games on Turner channels requires [[TV Everywhere]] authentication through provider) * [[CBS All Access]] (only CBS games, service subscription required) * [[CBSSports.com|CBS Sports website]] and app (only CBS games) * [[Bleacher Report]] website and ''Team Stream'' app (only Turner games, access requires subscription) * Watch TBS website and app (only TBS games, requires TV Everywhere authentication) * Watch TNT website and app (only TNT games, requires TV Everywhere authentication) * Watch truTV website and app (only truTV games, requires TV Everywhere authentication) * Websites and apps of cable, satellite, and OTT providers of CBS & Turner (access requires subscription)
====Audio==== Live audio of games will be available for streaming through the following means: * NCAA March Madness Live (website and app) * Westwood One Sports website * [[TuneIn]] (website and app) * Websites and apps of Westwood One Sports affiliates

The '''Ambronay Festival''' is a French [[List of opera festivals|opera festival]] and [[Early music festivals|early music festival]].<ref>[http://www.ambronay.org/ Festival d'Ambronay]</ref>
The festival has been running in October for 30 years<ref>Laure Roosen, Anthony Serex ''Le Petit Futé - Escapades autour de Lyon'' 2008 p30 "Démarré en 1980 à l'instigation de l'association Art et Musique, le festival de musique d'Ambronay gagne chaque année en.."</ref> and previously produced recordings with labels such as the Auvidis label.<ref>David Vandiedonck ''Qu'est-ce qui fait tourner le disque classique?: logiques éditoriales et place des interprètes '' 1999.</ref> 7 of 14 early recordings were with [[Jordi Savall]]. Since 2005 the Festival has been issuing recordings on its own label, Ambronay Éditions. More recently [[Leonardo García-Alarcón]] has been a regular performer and recording artist.
The main venue is the Benedictine Abbey [[Notre-Dame d'Ambronay]] of the village of [[Ambronay]]. The abbey has an exceptional acoustic<ref>''Franche-Comté'' 2007 Jura p104 "Grâce à une acoustique exceptionnelle, elle revêt chaque année une dimension internationale à l'occasion du Festival de musique baroque. ... Notre-Dame d'Ambronay accueille chaque année, en automne, un festival apprécié des mélomanes."</ref> In the abbey performing spaces are: Tour Dauphine, Chapiteau, Abbatiale. Other venues include the Théâtre de Bourg-en-Bresse, Monastery of Brou, also at [[Bourg-en-Bresse]], Théâtre des Augustins in [[Montluel]], the Abbaye Saint-Martin d'[[Ainay]], Lyon, and [[Belley Cathedral]].
==Themes== There is a theme for the festival each year:<ref>[http://www.ambronay.org/Festivals/ past brochures]</ref> * 2005 - including premieres of works by [[Francisco António de Almeida]] and [[Pedro António Avondano]] Ensemble Divino Sospiro, dir. Enrico Onofri. ''Tonos, cantadas et xácaras du Baroque espagnol'' by [[Los Músicos de Su Alteza]] dir. Luis Antonio González * 2006 - including [[Marco Marazzoli]] ''La Vita Humana'' [[Le Poème Harmonique]] dir. Vincent Dumestre. * 2007 - including [[Robert Carver (composer)|Robert Carver]], Ludus Modalis, dir. [[Bruno Boterf]] * 2008 - Women composers - including works by [[Johann Adolf Hasse]], [[Akadêmia]] dir. Françoise Lasserre * 2009 - celebrated 30 years by inviting the founders of the baroque movement. Including [[William Christie (musician)|William Christie]] directing Handel's ''Susanna''. * 2010 - celebrated the younger generation: [[Marco Mencoboni]] and Cantar Lontano, [[Fabio Biondi]], [[Manfredo Kraemer]], [[Jean-Christophe Spinosi]], and those still younger such as [[Geoffroy Jourdain]] and the Les Cris de Paris, [[Héloïse Gaillard]] and Ensemble Amarillis, [[Emmanuel Bardon]] and Canticum Novum, [[Sébastien d'Hérin]] (harpsichordist) and [[Leonardo García-Alarcón]]. * 2011 - ''Passion Bach'', with the Mass in B Minor conducted by Sigiswald Kuijken - and also Italian baroque; Caldara by [[Philippe Jaroussky]], Vivaldi by [[Max Emanuel Cenčić]] and Porpora by [[Vivica Genaux]].
==Discography== Recordings issued under the festival's own label, Ambronay Éditions include: *[[Johann Adolph Hasse|Hasse]]: ''Serpentes ignei in deserto''. Ensemble: [[Les Paladins (music ensemble)|Les Paladins]]. Conductor: [[Jérôme Correas]] (2006)<ref name = "Vickers2">Vickers, David (2007). [http://www.gramophone.co.uk/review/hasse-the-fiery-serpents-in-the-wilderness "Hasse: ''The Fiery Serpents in the Wilderness'': A superb package but is it enough to restore the composer's reputation?"]. ''[[Gramophone (magazine)|Gramophone]]''. Vol. 84, p. 90. Online version retrieved 23 June 2015.</ref> *[[Luigi Rossi|Rossi]] and [[Marco Marazzoli|Marazzoli]]: ''Soleils Baroques''. Ensemble: Les Paladins. Conductor: Jérôme Correas (2008)<ref name = "Roche">Roche, Elizabeth (January 2010). [http://em.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2010/01/29/em.cap129 "The moral oratorio"], p. 51. ''[[Early Music (journal)|Early Music]]'', Vol. 38, Issue 1</ref>

| shape1 = image | mark1 = FireIcon.svg | mark-coord1 = {{coord|38.39206|-122.24367}} | mark-size1 = 20 | label1 = Atlas Fire | label-pos1 = top | label-size1 = 14 |label-color1 = black | label-offset-x1= | label-offset-y1= |mark-title1=Atlas Fire |mark-image1= |mark-description1= }}
The '''Atlas Fire''' was a 2017 [[wildfire]] burning in [[Napa County]], [[California]] north of the city of [[Napa, California|Napa]], near [[Napa Soda Springs, California|Napa Soda Springs]]. It was one of [[October 2017 Northern California wildfires|fourteen large fires]] simultaneously burning in eight Northern California counties, in what was called the [[October 2017 Northern California wildfires|"Northern California firestorm"]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-napa-fires-20171009-story.html|title=At least 23 dead, 2,000 structures lost in Northern California firestorm, among worst in state's history|date=2017-10-09|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-10-10|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}}</ref> Governor [[Jerry Brown]] declared a state of emergency.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-ln-napa-fires-20171009-story.html|title=At least 10 dead, 1,500 structures lost in Northern California firestorm, among worst in state's history|date=9 October 2017|publisher=|via=LA Times}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2017/10/09/these-images-show-the-devastation-caused-by-californias-deadly-wine-country-fires/|title=‘Armageddon’: Apocalyptic images show the devastation caused by deadly wine-country fires|last=Hui|first=Mary|date=2017-10-12|work=Washington Post|access-date=2017-10-12|last2=Lac|first2=J. Freedom du|language=en-US|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>
[[File:11 November 2017, Napa, Sonoma fires, Landsat 8, bands 753.tif|thumb|[[Landsat 8]] OLI bands 753, Napa, Sonoma fires of October 2017]]
The fire, which started on October 8, had by October 12 burned {{Convert|51057|acre|km2|0}} of land, and was 77% contained.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=https://sf.eater.com/2017/10/12/16464532/north-bay-fire-containment-napa-sonoma-am-intel|title=North Bay Fire Updates: Tubbs Fire 10% Contained, Atlas Fire 3% Contained|work=Eater SF|access-date=2017-10-12}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-northern-california-fires-live-overnight-winds-were-milder-than-1507819015-htmlstory.html|title=Overnight winds were milder than expected, keeping Atlas fire's growth to a minimum|last=|first=|date=October 12, 2017|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=}}</ref> By October 12, the fire stretched from [[Lake Berryessa]] south to Napa, but a [[firebreak]] was established across Atlas Peak Road.<ref name=":0" />
==The Fire== {{Outdated section|date=November 2017}}
The fire began about 10 p.m. October 8 near [[Atlas Peak AVA|Atlas Peak]]. It started south, fed by winds, gusting to 28 miles per hour, and low [[relative humidity]] at 12%.<ref name="cbsnews.com">{{cite web|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/santa-rosa-fires-california-wine-country-evacuations/|title=At least 10 killed by fast-moving California wildfires, fire officials say|publisher=}}</ref>
On October 12, winds were forecast to reach 40 mph, but were lighter than expected, slowing the growth of the fire.<ref name=":0" />
== Evacuations == Evacuations started at [[Silverado Resort]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.golfdigest.com/story/fire-forces-evacuation-of-silverado-resort-hours-after-safeway-open-ended|title=Fire forces evacuation of Silverado Resort hours after Safeway Open ended - Golf Digest|last=Strege|first=John|work=Golf Digest|access-date=2017-10-09|language=en}}</ref> and at Vichy Avenue and Hagen Road area, then Montecito Boulevard and Monte Vista Avenue.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://napavalleyregister.com/news/local/update-wind-blown-fires-on-atlas-peak-partrick-road-and/article_bed444c7-3993-5d7e-a0bd-9cb252dbdc78.html|title=Wind-blown fires in Napa and Calistoga prompt major night evacuations, school closures|work=[[Napa Valley Register]]|first=Howard|last=Yune|publisher=[[Lee Enterprises]]}}</ref>
After the evacuation center at Crosswalk Church quickly reached maximum capacity, one was opened at [[Napa Valley College|Napa Valley College and St. Apollinaris Catholic Church]]. There are other evacuations centers such as: * Allan Witt Park, 1741 W Texas St, Fairfield, * Solano Community College, 4000 Suisun Valley Rd, Fairfield, and * Fairfield High School, 205 E. Atlantic Avenue, Fairfield.<ref name="auto"/> * [[Sonoma Raceway]] open their campgrounds.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.timesheraldonline.com/article/NH/20171010/SPORTS/171019965|title=Sonoma Raceway opening campground to evacuees seeking temporary refuge|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://abc7news.com/atlas-fire-flaring-up-outside-american-canyon/2523532/|title=Atlas Fire flaring up in Napa County|last=Keller|first=Matt|date=2017-10-12|work=ABC7 San Francisco|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
The evacuations for Solano County are Upper and Lower Green Valley, Eastridge. The advisory is for the Lakes, and The Shopping Centers for Cordelia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sanfrancisco.cbslocal.com/2017/10/11/encroaching-atlas-fire-spurs-evacuations-for-parts-of-fairfield/|title=Encroaching Atlas Fire Spurs Evacuations For Parts Of Fairfield|publisher=}}</ref> In [[Sonoma, California|Sonoma]], there were mandatory evacuation orders first at Seventh Street East, Castle Road, and Lovall Valley Road; then at East Napa Street.<reF>{{cite web|url=http://m.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Live-updates-23-dead-in-Wine-Country-fires-12271728.php|title=Live updates: Fire death toll at 29 in Northern California fires|publisher=}}</reF> An evacuation advisory was issued for parts of the city of Napa.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.kcra.com/article/3500-homes-businesses-destroyed-by-fires-in-norcal-wine-country-weather-conditions-fan-flames/12823343|title=New evacuations ordered as Napa County wildfires grow|last=Staff|first=KCRA|date=2017-10-12|work=KCRA|access-date=2017-10-12|language=en}}</ref>

{{Infobox film | name = Bolinao 52 | image = | image size = | caption = | director = Duc Nguyen | producer = | writer = | narrator = | starring = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | distributor = | released = March 19, 2007 | runtime = | country = | language = | budget = | preceded by = | followed by = }} '''''Bolinao 52''''' is a [[Documentary film|documentary]] by [[Vietnamese American]] director [[Duc Nguyen]] about the Vietnamese [[boat people]] ship that was originally stranded in the Pacific Ocean in 1988. During their 37 days at sea, the group encountered violent storms and engine failures. They fought their thirst and hunger and a US Navy ship reportedly refused to rescue them, forcing the boat people to starve despite resorting to [[cannibalism]]. Only 52 out of the 110 boat people survived the tragedy and were rescued by Filipino fishermen who brought them to [[Bolinao, Pangasinan|Bolinao Island, Philippines]].
==Release Date== ''Bolinao 52'' premiered on March 19, 2007, in [[San Francisco, California|San Francisco]] and on March 24, 2007, in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]] at the [[San Francisco International Asian American Film Festival]].
==See also== * [[Boat people]] * [[Vượt Sóng]] * [[Vietnamese International Film Festival]]

{{other uses}} {{Infobox company | name = Butterball LLC | logo = Butterball Logo.jpg | logo_size = 200px | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = 2006 | location = [[Garner, North Carolina]], [[United States|U.S.]] | key_people = Kerry Doughty, President and CEO | num_employees = 5500<ref name=Smithfield/> | industry = Poultry | products = [[turkey meat|Turkey]] | revenue = $1.5 billion (2008) | operating_income = | net_income = | owner =Maxwell Farms and [[Seaboard Corporation]] | homepage = [http://www.butterball.com/ Butterball] }}
'''Butterball''' is a [[brand]] of [[turkey meat|turkey]] and other [[poultry]] products produced by Butterball LLC. The company manufactures food products in the United States and internationally — specializing in turkey, cured deli meats, raw roasts and specialty products such as soups and salads, sandwiches, and entrées.
'''Butterball LLC''' was a [[joint venture]] of [[Smithfield Foods]] and [[Maxwell Farms Inc.]],<ref>[http://www.smithfieldfoods.com/Investor/Press/press_view.asp?ID=354 Smithfield Foods::Investor Information::Press Releases<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> an affiliate of the Goldsboro Milling Co.<ref name="titan">{{cite web | title = Butterball acquisition creates a turkey titan | publisher = Refrigerated Transporter, Oct 4, 2006 | url = http://refrigeratedtrans.com/news/Carolina-Turkeys-acquires-Butterball/index.html?imw=Y}}</ref> [[Seaboard Corporation]] bought Smithfield's stake in Butterball in 2010. The company sells over one billion pounds of turkey a year.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} Though the ''Butterball'' brand has been formally recognized since 1940, Butterball LLC was formed in 2006.
In Canada, the rights to Butterball are owned by Exceldor Foods Ltd.
==Products== According to Butterball, the following products are sold under the Butterball name:<ref>[http://www.butterball.com/en/main_canvas.jsp?includePage=product_home.jsp&t=Products%20Landing%20Page&s0=products&s1= Turkey Products|Butterball] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061117162328/http://www.butterball.com/en/main_canvas.jsp?includePage=product_home.jsp&t=Products%20Landing%20Page&s0=products&s1= |date=November 17, 2006 }}</ref>
{{Col-begin}} {{Col-break}} *whole turkeys *turkey cuts *[[cold cut]]s *[[sausage]] *[[turkey bacon]] {{Col-break}} *turkey medallions, strips, chicken strips *turkey franks *ground turkey *frozen turkey burgers, mignons, meatballs {{Col-break}}
{{col-end}}
Among numerous other brands, [[England|English]]-bred Butterball turkeys are sold in the [[United Kingdom]] during [[Christmas]] time for the Christmas [[Christmas dinner#United Kingdom|feast]].
==History== [[Image:Butterball plant, Longmont, CO IMG 5214.JPG|200px|right|thumb|The Butterball plant in downtown [[Longmont, Colorado|Longmont]], [[Colorado]]]]
The name Butterball was originally registered as trademark #378,438 on June 11, 1940, by Ada Walker of [[Wyoming, Ohio|Wyoming]], [[Ohio]]. Leo Peters purchased the trademark in February 1951. Leo Peters licensed the name to [[JBS USA|Swift and Co.]] for 10 years before selling it in the 1960s. Peters sold the name "Butterball" to Swift, which was acquired by [[ConAgra]] in 1990.
Leo Peters retained rights to use the name '''Butterball Farms''' for his butter products<ref name="retained">{{cite web |title=Butterball Farms, History |publisher=Butterball Farms, History |url=http://butterballfarms.com/Our_History.aspx |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708105209/http://butterballfarms.com/Our_History.aspx |archivedate=2011-07-08 |df= }}</ref> and the company operates today as Butterball Farms, Inc., producing and marketing shaped [[butter]] products.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070928225218/http://www.butterballfarms.com/foodservice/products2.php Butterball Farms product page]</ref>
In October 2006, ConAgra's Butterball branded turkey business was sold to [[North Carolina]]-based '''Carolina Turkeys,''' making Carolina Turkey the largest turkey producer in the United States.<ref name="largest">{{cite news | title = Carolina Turkey gobbles up Butterball for $325M | publisher = Triangle Business Journal, October 2, 2006 | url = http://triangle.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2006/10/02/daily9.html | date=October 2, 2006}}</ref> The company, located southeast of Raleigh, NC in [[Mount Olive, North Carolina]] on the Wayne and Duplin county line, subsequently renamed itself Butterball LLC.<ref>[https://www.usatoday.com/money/industries/food/2006-11-21-butterball_x.htm USA Today: Sale of Butterball turkey business not expected to change Thanksgiving icon]</ref>
In 2008, the company moved its headquarters to a new $12 million building in Greenfield North off Interstate 40 in [[Garner, North Carolina]]. The headquarters has a "customer experience center" with a special kitchen for promotional demonstrations.<ref name="major deal">{{cite news | title = A major deal that was no turkey | publisher = Triangle Business Journal, November 16, 2007 | url = http://triangle.bizjournals.com/triangle/stories/2007/11/19/tidbits2.html | date=November 19, 2007}}</ref>
Smithfield offered $200 million to Maxwell Farms for the portion of Butterball that Smithfield did not own. Chief executive C. Larry Pope said at that time that he hoped Maxwell Farms would spend more on the company's facilities and marketing. A decision had to be made whether to buy Maxwell's share or sell Smithfield's. On September 10, 2010, Smithfield announced the sale of its 49 percent share of Butterball for an estimated $175 million. Maxwell Farms will sell 50 percent of Butterball to Seaboard Corp.<ref name=Smithfield>{{cite news|url=http://www.newsobserver.com/2010/09/10/673672/smithfield-to-sell-its-stake-in.html|title=Smithfield to sell its stake in Butterball|last=Felberbaum|first=Michael|work=[[News & Observer]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=2010-09-10|accessdate=2010-09-10}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
==Corporate== Walter “Gator” Pelletier, past chairman of the [[National Turkey Federation]], is Butterball LLC's corporate secretary — managing all operating activities from turkey production and directing Maxwell Farms, the managing partner of Butterball. Pelletier is also president of Maxwell Farms, Inc., vice president of Goldsboro Milling Company, and secretary-treasurer of Maxwell Foods, Inc. Pelletier had joined Goldsboro Milling Company in 1981.<ref name="major deal-2">{{cite web |title=NTF Chairman Says Change in Attitude Will be Needed to Address Numerous Issues |publisher=Eatturnkey.com, National Turkey Federation, February 7, 2009 |url=http://www.eatturkey.com/news/news_detail.cgi/194/0 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130121184504/http://www.eatturkey.com/news/news_detail.cgi/194/0 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-01-21 |df= }}</ref>
==Turkey Talk-Line== Beginning in late 1981, Butterball has maintained a toll-free telephone line called the Turkey Talk-Line to help customers with cooking and preparation questions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adweek.com/brand-marketing/butterballs-turkey-hotline-has-been-preventing-thanksgiving-disasters-35-years-174358/ |publisher=Ad Week |title=Butterball’s Turkey Hotline Has Been Preventing Thanksgiving Disasters for 35 Years |date=November 1, 2016 |author=Robert Klara}}</ref> Eleven thousand people called in 1981, and in recent years the number has grown to over 200,000 each holiday season. The most frequent question asked is how long a turkey takes to defrost.
In ''[[The West Wing]]'' episode "[[The Indians in the Lobby]]", President [[Josiah Bartlet]] calls the number (referred to as the "Butterball Hotline" in the script) to discuss stuffing and cooking his Thanksgiving turkey.
==Criticism== Animal welfare activists such as [[Mercy for Animals]],<ref>{{Citation|last=Free Animal Video|title=Butterball Turkey Animal Cruelty Undercover Video MFA|date=2014-04-25|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Bhi-Gg2b46A|accessdate=2016-11-13}}</ref> the [[Humane Society of the United States]], and [[PETA]] have accused Butterball of animal cruelty.<ref name="butterballabuse">{{cite web |url=http://butterballabuse.com/ |title=Butterball Abuse |date=December 28, 2011 |publisher=Mercy for Animals |accessdate=December 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.peta.org/features/butterball-peta-investigation.aspx|title=Butterball's House of Horrors: A PETA Undercover Investigation |date=2010-10-21|accessdate=December 28, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.humanesociety.org/news/press_releases/2009/12/shareholder_resolution_urges.html |title=Shareholder Resolution Urges Smithfield to Help Decrease Suffering of Butterball Turkeys |date=December 22, 2009 |publisher=Humane Society of the United States |accessdate=December 29, 2011}}</ref> These organizations cite intentional cruelty inflicted on the birds, as well as the incidental cruelty inherent in the slaughter methods used, and the breeding practices which produce animals too large to reproduce without human intervention.
In October 2012, a Mercy for Animals investigator documented a pattern of abuse and neglect at numerous Butterball turkey operations in North Carolina. The investigation revealed workers kicking and stomping on birds, dragging them by their wings and necks, and throwing turkeys onto the ground or on top of other birds; birds suffering from serious untreated illnesses and injuries, including open sores, infections, and broken bones; and workers grabbing birds by their wings or necks and violently slamming them into tiny transport crates with no regard for their welfare.<ref>{{cite web|title=Butterball Abuse: Undercover Investigation Exposes Shocking Cruelty...Again!|url=http://www.butterballabuse.com/|publisher=Mercy For Animals}}</ref>
This investigation occurred less than one year after a Mercy for Animals undercover investigation into a different Butterball turkey facility led to five workers being charged with criminal [[cruelty to animals]]. Mercy for Animals’ 2011 investigation at a Butterball turkey factory farm in Shannon, Hoke County, North Carolina revealed Butterball workers violently kicking and stomping on birds, dragging them by their wings and necks, slamming them into transport crates, and leaving turkeys to suffer from serious untreated injuries and infections.<ref>{{cite web|title=Butterball Abuse|url=http://www.butterballabuse.com/|publisher=Mercy For Animals|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref> As a result of the investigation, North Carolina officials raided the facility and arrested several employees.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galli|first=Cindy|title=Butterball Turkey Raided Amid Animal Abuse Allegations|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/butterball-turkey-raided-amid-animal-abuse-allegations/story?id=15249456#.Tvyp6lb4WSo|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=25 September 2012}}</ref>
In August 2012, Butterball worker Brian Douglas pleaded guilty to felony cruelty to animals—marking the first-ever felony conviction for cruelty to factory-farmed birds in United States history.<ref>{{cite web|last=Runkle|first=Nathan|title=Making History: Butterball Case Marks First-Ever Felony Conviction for Cruelty to Factory-Farmed Birds|url=http://www.mfablog.org/2012/08/making-history-butterball-conviction-marks-first-ever-felony-conviction-for-cruelty-to-factory-farme.html|publisher=Mercy For Animals|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Winter|first=Michael|title=Ex-N.C. turkey farm worker pleads guilty to animal cruelty|url=http://content.usatoday.com/communities/ondeadline/post/2012/08/nc-turkey-farm-worker-pleads-guilty-to-animal-cruelty/1|publisher=USA Today|accessdate=5 September 2012|date=28 August 2012}}</ref> Several days later, another Butterball employee, Rueben Mendoza, pleaded guilty to misdemeanor cruelty to animals and felony identity theft.<ref>{{cite web|title=Breaking News: Another Butterball Worker Pleads Guilty to Cruelty to Animals|url=http://www.mfablog.org/2012/08/breaking-news-another-butterball-worker-pleads-guilty-to-cruelty-to-animals.html|publisher=Mercy For Animals|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref>
In February 2013, two more Butterball workers, Terry Johnson and Billy McBride, were found guilty of misdemeanor animal cruelty as a result of MFA's investigation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Runkle|first=Nathan|title=Breaking News: Two More Butterball Workers Convicted of Cruelty to Animals|url=http://www.mfablog.org/2013/02/breaking-news-two-more-butterball-workers-convicted-of-cruelty-to-animals.html|publisher=Mercy For Animals|accessdate=23 February 2013}}</ref>
In addition to the felony and misdemeanor cruelty convictions, MFA’s investigation at Butterball uncovered government corruption. Dr. Sarah Jean Mason, the director of Animal Health Programs with the North Carolina Department of Agriculture, was arrested and pleaded guilty to obstruction of justice charges after admitting to warning Butterball about the raid by law enforcement and potentially compromising the criminal cruelty investigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=More animal cruelty arrests at Butterball facility in Hoke County|url=http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2012/feb/17/more-animal-cruelty-arrests-at-butterball-facility-ar-1941598/|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130127152549/http://www2.journalnow.com/news/2012/feb/17/more-animal-cruelty-arrests-at-butterball-facility-ar-1941598/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=27 January 2013|publisher=Winston-Salem Journal|accessdate=5 September 2012}}</ref>

{{Infobox wrestling event |name = CMLL Día de Muertos (2018) |image = CMLL Dia de Muertos 2018.jpg |alt = |caption = Official poster for the event |tagline=Dioses en Guerra Gods at War |promotion = [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] |date = November 2, 2018<ref name=DDM2018/> |date_aired = |attendance = |venue = [[Arena México]]<ref name=DDM2018/> |city = [[Mexico City, Mexico]]<ref name=DDM2018/> |liveevent = Y |lastevent = [[Blue Panther 40th Anniversary Show]] |nextevent =TBA |event = CMLL Día de Muertos |lastevent2 = [[CMLL Día de Muertos (2017)]] |nextevent2 = TBA }} The '''CMLL Día de Muertos (2018)''' (Spanish for "Day of the Dead") is a [[professional wrestling]] [[Supercard|supercard event]], scripted and produced by the Mexican ''[[Lucha Libre]]'' [[professional wrestling promotion|promotion]] [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL). The show took place on November 2, 2018 in CMLL's main venue, [[Arena México]], in [[Mexico City|Mexico City, Mexico]] and celebrated the Mexican [[Day of the Dead]] celebration. Many of the wrestlers working the show wore the traditional Día de Muertos face and body paint for the Día de Muerto event. From the fourth match on the losing wrestlers were be dragged to ''El Inframundo'' ("The Underworld"), a side entrance in the arena, by a group of wrestlers dressed up as minions of the ruler of the underworld.<ref name=ReydelInframundo>{{cite web | url=https://superluchas.com/cmll-una-mirada-semanal-al-cmll-del-2-al-8-noviembre-2017/ | title=CMLL: Una mirada semanal al CMLL (del 2 al 8 de noviembre de 2017) | date=November 10, 2017 | accessdate=August 8, 2018 | author=Dark Angelita | work=SuperLuchas | language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=Medio>{{cite web | url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/lucha-libre/2017/11/04/sanson-se-proclamo-el-primer-rey-del-inframundo-en-el-cmll | title=Sansón se proclamó el primer Rey del Inframundo en el CMLL | date=November 4, 2017 | accessdate=October 3, 2018 | work=MedioTiempo | publisher=[[MSN]] | language=Spanish | first=Apolo |last=Valdés}}</ref>
As part of the show [[Sansón (wrestler)|Sansón]] successfully defended the ''Rey del Inframundo'' ("King of the Underworld") championship that he won at the [[CMLL Día de Muertos (2017)|2017 Día de Muertos show]] against challenger [[Templario]]. The main event was a ''[[Relevos increíbles]]'' (Miss-matched team match) where the ''technico'' (those that portray the "good guys") [[Fénix (wrestler)|King Phoenix]] teamed with his brother [[Penta 0M]] and [[Último Guerrero]], who are both ''rudos'' ("the bad guys"), losing to the team of [[Diamante Azul]], [[L.A. Park]], and [[Michael Elgin]]. The show featured four additional matches.
==Storylines== The 2018 Dia de Muertos show features six [[Professional wrestling match types|professional wrestling matches]] scripted by CMLL with some wrestlers involved in scripted feuds. Wrestlers portray either [[Heel (professional wrestling)|heels]] (referred to as ''rudos'' in Mexico, those that play the part of the "bad guys") or [[Face (professional wrestling)|faces]] (''técnicos'' in Mexico, the "good guy" characters) as they perform.<ref name="Mondo">{{cite book | author= Madigan, Dan | title= Mondo Lucha a Go Go: the bizarre & honorable world of wild Mexican wrestling | publisher= HarperColins Publisher | year= 2007 | chapter = "Okay... what is Lucha Libre?" | page = 31 | quote=featuring clearly distinguished good guys and bad guys, or técnicos and rudos | isbn=978-0-06-085583-3|location=New York, New York}}</ref>
At the [[CMLL Día de Muertos (2017)|2017 Día de Muertos show]], [[Sansón (wrestler)|Sansón]] outlasted [[El Cuatrero]], [[Diamante Azul]], [[Forastero]], [[Hechicero]], [[Mistico II|Mistico]], [[Soberano Jr.]] and [[Valiente (wrestler)|Valiente]] in a ''[[torneo cibernetico]]'' elimination match to become the first ever ''Rey del Inframundo'' ("King of the Underworld").<ref name=ReydelInframundo/><ref name=Medio/> While Sansón was given a championship belt to symbolize his victory it is not a championship, but a tournament trophy that is not defended outside of the annual tournament in the vein of CMLL's [[Leyenda de Plata]] or [[Leyenda de Azul]] tournaments.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/lucha-libre/2018/10/24/el-cmll-realizara-segunda-edicion-torneo-rey-del-inframundo | title=El CMLL realizará segunda edición torneo Rey del Inframundo |date=October 24, 2018 | accessdate=October 28, 2018 | work=MedioTiempo | publisher=[[MSN]] | language=Spanish}}</ref> On the October 26, 2018 [[CMLL Super Viernes]] show 12 wrestlers competed in the first round of the 2018 ''Rey del Inframundo'' tournament, with [[Templario]] winning the match over a field that included [[Audaz]], [[The Panther (wrestler)|Black Panther]], [[El Cuatrero]], [[Esfinge]], [[Flyer (wrestler)|Flyer]], [[Forastero]], [[Guerrero Maya Jr.]], [[Hirai Kawato|Kawato San]], [[Tiger (wrestler)|Tiger]], [[Tritón (wrestler)|Tritón]], and [[Virus (wrestler)|Virus]], thus qualifying for the final match against Sansón on November 2.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.thegladiatores.com/derrota-con-sabor-a-victoria-para-rush-y-compania/ | title=Derrota con sabor a victoria para Rush y compañía. | work=The Gladiatores | language=Spanish | date=October 27, 2018 | accessdate=October 28, 2018 | first=Alfonso | last=Lizarraga}}</ref>
==Matches== {{Pro Wrestling results table |results=<ref name=DDM2018>{{cite web | url= https://ovaciones.com/sanson-bicampeon-del-inframundo/ | title=Sansón, bicampeón del inframundo | date=November 3, 2018 | accessdate=November 4, 2018 | work=Ovaciones | first=Arturo | last=Rosas Plata | language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=DDMMedio>{{cite web | url=http://www.mediotiempo.com/lucha-libre/2018/11/03/sanson-se-mantuvo-como-rey-del-inframundo-en-el-cmll| title=Sansón se mantuvo como Rey del Inframundo en el CMLL | date=November 3, 2018 | accessdate=November 4, 2018 | work=MedioTiempo | publisher=[[MSN]] | language=Spanish}}</ref><ref name=DDMGladoatores>{{cite web | url=http://www.thegladiatores.com/sanson-continua-como-campeon-del-inframundo/ | title=Sansón continúa como campeón del Inframundo. | date=November 3, 2018 | accessdate=November 4, 2018 | language=Spanish | work=The Gladiatores | first=Alfonso | last=Lizarraga}}</ref>
|match1= El Coyote and Grako defeated [[Oro Jr.]] and [[Súper Astro Jr.]] |stip1=[[Tag team|Best two-out-of-three falls tag team match]]
|match2= Átomo, [[El Gallo (wrestler)|Gallito]], and [[Microman (wrestler)|Microman]] defeated Chamuel, [[El Alebrije (wrestler)|Mije]], and [[Mini Máximo|Perico Zakarías]] |stip2=[[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Trios rules (Relevos Australianos)|Best two-out-of-three falls six-man tag team match]]
|match3= [[Hechicero]], [[Rey Bucanero]], and [[El Terrible]] defeated [[Ángel de Oro]], [[Audaz]], and [[Stuka Jr.]] |stip3=Best two-out-of-three falls six-man tag team match
|match4= [[Atlantis (wrestler)|Atlantis]], [[El Hijo de L.A. Park]], and [[Místico II|Místico]] defeated [[Bárbaro Cavernario]] and ''[[Los Hijos del Infierno]] ([[Ephesto]] and [[Mephisto (wrestler)|Mephisto]]) |stip4=Best two-out-of-three falls six-man tag team match

{{Infobox book | name = C | title_orig = | translator = | image = File:C (Tom McCarthy novel).jpg | caption = | author = [[Tom McCarthy (novelist)|Tom McCarthy]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United Kingdom | language = English | subject = | genre = | publisher = | release_date = 2010 | english_release_date = | media_type = Print (Hardcover & Paperback) | pages = 400 | isbn = | dewey = | congress = | oclc = | preceded_by = | followed_by = <!--for books in a series--> }}
'''''C''''' is a 2010 novel written by [[Tom McCarthy (novelist)|Tom McCarthy]]. ''C'' is McCarthy's third novel and sixth book. The novel was shortlisted for the [[Booker Prize]].<ref name=carey>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/booknews/7913342/Peter-Carey-could-be-three-time-Booker-winner.html | location=London | work=The Daily Telegraph | first=Stephen | last=Adams | title=Peter Carey could be three-time Booker winner | date=27 July 2010}}</ref> Critics were polarized by the work.<ref name=carey/>
==Plot== The novel revolves around Serge Carrefax, born in the late 19th century in England. The plot follows his life before and after World War I.
==Themes== A major theme in the novel is communication, and the way technology influences the way individuals and societies communicate.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/12/books/review/Egan-t.html|title=Code World|last=Egan|first=Jennifer|date=8 September 2010|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2010/jul/31/c-tom-mccarthy-novel-review|title=C by Tom McCarthy|last=Tayler|first=Christopher|date=30 July 2010|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref>
==Reception== Jennifer Egan, writing for the New York Times, referred to the novel as fusing "Pynchonesque revelry in signs and codes with the lush psychedelics of William Burroughs".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/09/12/books/review/Egan-t.html|title=Code World|last=Egan|first=Jennifer|date=8 September 2010|accessdate=30 September 2014}}</ref> Leo Robson, in a review for the New Statesman, describes the book as "full of familiar delights and familiar tedium". It continues "After a certain point, most sentences go something like this (not a parody): "Everything seems connected: disparate locations twitch and burst into activity like limbs reacting to impulses sent from elsewhere in the body, booms and jibs obeying levers at the far end of a complex set of ropes and cogs and relays."<ref>[http://www.newstatesman.com/books/2010/08/mccarthy-novel-serge-smith ''New Statesman'' article]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:2010 British novels]] [[Category:British historical novels]] [[Category:Historical fiction|Novels]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox military conflict |conflict=Callao affair |partof=the [[Peruvian War of Independence]] | image= USS Macedonian in Ireland.png | image_size = 300 |caption=''The rebuilt USS Macedonian in [[Ireland]] during the [[Great Famine (Ireland)|Great Famine]].'' |date=November 5–6, 1820 |place=[[Callao]], [[Peru]], [[Pacific Ocean]] |result=Spanish vow to punish those responsible for attacks on American shipping. |combatant1={{flag|United States|1820}} |combatant2={{flag|Spain|1785}} |commander1={{flagicon|United States Navy}} [[John Downes (naval officer)|John Downes]] |commander2={{flagicon|Spain|1785}} [[Joaquin de la Pezuela]] |strength1=1 [[frigate]]
6 [[schooner]]s |strength2=1 [[fort]] |casualties1=2 killed
6 wounded{{cite web|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/faqs/faq56-1.htm |title=Casualties: US Navy and Marine Corps |publisher=[[United States Navy]] |date=February 22, 2010 |accessdate=July 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070605234857/http://www.history.navy.mil/faqs/faq56-1.htm |archivedate=June 5, 2007 |df= }}
1 frigate damaged
2 schooners damaged |casualties2=none |notes= }} {{Campaignbox Peruvian War of Independence}} The '''Callao affair''' occurred in November 1820, during the [[Peruvian War of Independence]]. It began when a [[Spain|Spanish]] fort opened fire on the [[United States]] warship [[USS Macedonian (1810)|USS ''Macedonian'']]. Though the ship was damaged, the Americans did not violate their neutrality by counterattacking. On the following day, a boat filled with [[United States Navy]] sailors was attacked, resulting in the deaths of two seamen and the wounding of eight others. Two days after that, an American merchant ship was attacked and her crew had to abandon ship. Ultimately, there was no significant response by the United States to the attacks on their shipping and their citizens, though the Spanish government vowed to punish the perpetrators.De Kay, pp. 167–70 ==Affair== [[File:Peru.Lima.1889.Detalle.Stieler.png|200px|right|thumb|''A 19th century map of Peru showing the location of Fortaleza del Real Felipe and the batteries which fired on USS Macedonian''.]] Inspired by the French revolution in 1789, and the Peruvian revolution, the people of [[Chile]] joined forces with the rebel Peruvians and revolted against Spanish authority in 1820. As result, a rebel [[First Chilean Navy Squadron]] under [[Scotland|Scottish]] [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] [[Thomas Cochrane, 10th Earl of Dundonald|Thomas Cochrane]] attacked the Spanish fleet anchored off [[Callao]] on the night of November 5, during which the rebels captured the 44 gun frigate [[Esmeralda (1791)|''Esmeralda'']] with heavy loss of life to the Spanish defenders. The capture of the ship crippled Spain's operational capabilities in the [[Pacific Ocean]] and infuriated the [[Royalist (Spanish American Revolution)|Royalist]] inhabitants of Callao. During the battle, the [[frigate]] USS ''Macedonian'', under Captain [[John Downes (naval officer)|John Downes]], was also at port with the mission of protecting six American merchant [[schooner]]s which were being harassed by both the Chilean fleet and the Spanish on shore. Because the ''Macedonian'' was so close to the battle area, the Spanish military in Callao assumed that she had supported Cochrane's fleet in the attack. So instead of aiming for the Chilean ships, the [[garrison]] opened fire on the frigate and one of the American merchantmen with [[heated shot|hot shot]] from [[Fortaleza del Real Felipe]].Glenn, p. 108 Multiple rounds ripped through the ships' rigging though the damage was repairable and no Americans were harmed. The ''Macedonian''{{'}}s [[carpenter]], [[Samuel Holbrook]], later described the incident; "''Their shot flew round us like hail, cutting away our cross-jack yard, and much of our rigging. Many of the red hot shot struck near us.''" Captain Downes was in [[Lima, Peru|Lima]] at the time and a [[first lieutenant]] was in command and he ordered the sails hoisted to bring the vessel out of the fort's range. On the following day, the lieutenant sent the [[Destroyer tender|tender]] ''Buckskin'' filled with sailors into port for provisions. However, while the sailors were still heading to shore, Spanish troops at the docks opened fire, killing two men and wounding six others. Holbrook described the scene; "''blood and brain scattered round the inside as though a bullock had been killed in her.''" There was no landing as some sources claim and the survivors went back to their ship without obtaining the fresh food they were looking for.Glenn, p. 109 At the same time that the ''Macedonian'' sailors were attacked, American and British merchantmen were being looted in the port and two days later, on November 8, the American schooner ''Rampart'' was attacked by the fort and heavily damaged while trying to offload her cargo, forcing her crew to abandon ship. The ''Macedonian'' also took on board that day several American and British refugees who were in fear of being killed by the natives. Captain Downes was still not interested in exacting redress for the three incidents but he did send the Spanish [[Viceroy]] [[Joaquin de la Pezuela]] a letter of protest.Long, p. 79{{cite news|url=http://www.freefictionbooks.org/books/b/23924-blackwoods-edinburgh-magazine-volume-60-no-369-july-1846?start=3|title=Dr Tschudi arrived in the bay of Callao|magazine=[[Blackwood's Magazine|Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine]]|volume=60|issue=369|date=July 1846|page=4|accessdate=July 2, 2011}} ==Aftermath== Pezuela said he would punish those responsible but whether he actually did so or not remains unknown. Due to the blockade, Captain Downes was afraid his ship would be seized as it was illegally carrying over a million dollars in Spanish gold, something Cochrane's [[espionage|spies]] had informed him of some time prior. So, when the Americans were leaving Callao, they expected to have to fight their way past the Chilean fleet, but Cochrane ignored the frigate and let it go without any opposition. Captain Downes remained off the [[South America]]n coast until March 1821 to protect American merchant sailors, many of whom were either imprisoned by the viceroy, or murdered by the Spanish military and their Peruvian subjects. The murder and imprisonment of United States citizens at Lima and Callao was attributed to the fact that some of the victims were captured from ships of Cochrane's fleet and were legally [[prisoners of war]], though many of the American victims were not involved in the conflict and were killed along with other innocent foreigners. In the end, there was no retaliation by the United States in response to the attacks on their vessels or their citizens, other than the feeble letter of protest from Downes.Glenn, p. 110De Kay, pp. 169–70 ==See also== *[[Bahia Incident|Bahia incident]] *[[Rio de Janeiro Affair]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book|last=Glenn|first=Myra C.|title=Jack Tar's Story: The Autobiographies and Memoirs of Sailors in Antebellum America|year=2010|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-19368-0}} *{{cite book|last=De Kay|first=James T.|title=Chronicles of the Frigate Macedonian, 1809–1922|year=2000|publisher=W. W. Norton & Company|isbn=0-393-32024-3}} *{{cite book|last=Long|first=David F.|title=Gold braid and foreign relations: diplomatic activities of U.S. naval officers, 1798–1883|year=1988|publisher=US Naval Institute Press|isbn=0-87021-228-1}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Callao Affair}} [[Category:1820 in Peru]] [[Category:Maritime incidents in 1820]] [[Category:United States Navy in the 19th century]] [[Category:Peruvian War of Independence]] [[Category:Spain–United States relations]] [[Category:Combat incidents]] [[Category:First Chilean Navy Squadron]] [[Category:November 1820 events]]

revision.text:
{{About||the 1597 setting of the original Italian libretto by Jacopo Peri|Dafne}} {{italic title}} [[File:Daphne chased by Apollo.jpg|thumb|''Daphne [[Apollo and Daphne|Chased by Apollo]]'', by [[Giovanni Battista Tiepolo]], 1744]] '''''Die Dafne''''' (1627) to a libretto by [[Martin Opitz]] (which survives), and music by [[Heinrich Schütz]] (which is lost), has traditionally been regarded as the first [[German opera]],{{clarify|reason=What does that imply? That everything was sung?|date=January 2014}} though it has also been proposed more recently that it was in fact a spoken [[drama]] with inserted song and [[ballet]] numbers.
==History of the work== Opitz was already a friend of Schütz and in all wrote twelve German [[madrigal]] texts for him. In 1625 and 1626 Opitz visited the [[Dresden court]], to work with Schütz on a ''Sing-Comoedie'' based on the model of [[Jacopo Peri]]'s ''[[Dafne]]''.<ref>Isabella Van Elferen -Mystical Love in the German Baroque: Theology, Poetry, Music - 2009 -Page 31 "The Dresden Kapellmeister Heinrich Schütz was a friend of Martin Opitz, who wrote twelve German madrigal texts for him.26 In 1625 and 1626 Opitz visited Dresden, where he worked with Schütz on a “Sing-Comoedie” entitled Dafne (first ..."</ref> Opitz rewrote the libretto after [[Rinuccini]], translating it into [[Alexandrine verse]], and his libretto was so highly regarded that it was later adapted back into Italian by later Italian librettists.<ref>A Alms Adapting an adaptation: Martin Opitz's Dafne among the Italians 2012 em.oxfordjournals.org/content/early/2012/02/23/em.car119.full 23 Feb 2012 "The 1627 Opitz–Schütz Dafne was in a sense a paradigmatic work: it presented a case that German opera could develop a lasting presence by ..."</ref> Opitz and Schütz' were probably attracted by religious content of the work, rather than the purely pagan mythology of Dafne or Euridice.<ref>Judith Popovich Aikin -A language for German opera: the development for forms and ... 2002 "Schutz's enthusiasm (and Opitz's) can be ascribed, according to Mayer, to the religious content of the work, which he thought should be much more attractive to both Germans than the pagan mythology of Dafne or Euridice."</ref> The electoral secretary to the Saxon Court, Johann Seusse also exerted influence on the project.<ref>Schütz-Jahrbuch: Volume 30; Volume 30 Internationale Heinrich Schütz-Gesellschaft, 2008 "Eine erste Begegnung Seusses mit Opitz könnte im August 1626 in Dresden erfolgt sein, als Schütz und Opitz das gemeinsame Dafne-Projekt besprachen. Opitz weilte in jenem Sommer in diplomatischer Mission des Burggrafen von Dohna in ..."</ref>
==Modern scholarly reevaluation== Although long unquestioned as "the first German opera"{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} the performance started no notable tradition in Germany, and [[:de:Wolfram Steude|Wolfram Steude]] (1991) made the controversial proposal that Dafne was in fact a spoken drama with inserted song and [[ballet]] numbers. Consequently recent publications such as the latest edition of the New Grove Dictionary of Opera are more cautious in attribution of the "first German opera" claim. <ref>Bettina Varwig Histories of Heinrich Schütz - Page 94 2011 "In 1991, Wolfram Steude published his controversial proposal that Dafne amounted to nothing more than a piece of 'spoken theatre with inserted song and ballet numbers'.2 The latest edition of the New Grove Dictionary of Opera ..."</ref>
==Other dramatic works by Schütz== Two other large scale sung dramas by Schütz are also lost: *''Orpheus und Eurydike'' (Dresden, 1638)<ref name=Goldsmiths>{{cite web |url=http://www.goldsmiths.ac.uk/aurifex/issue1/smart.html |title=David Schirmer's Ballet von dem Paris und der Helena (1650): An Example of Early German Musical Drama |accessdate=2008-06-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070824120729/http://www.goldsmiths.ac.uk/aurifex/issue1/smart.html |archivedate=2007-08-24 |df= }}</ref> — a ballet based on the [[Orpheus#Death of Eurydice|myth]] about Orpheus and Eurydice, with [[libretto]] by [[August Buchner]].<ref name=Goldsmiths/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/august-buchner|title=German Literature Companion: August Buchner|accessdate=2008-06-10}}</ref> *''Paris und Helena'' five-act Sing-Ballet to a libretto by David Schirmer. For the double wedding in Dresden of the brothers [[Maurice, Duke of Saxe-Zeitz]] and [[Christian I, Duke of Saxe-Merseburg]].
==See also== * [[Origins of opera]] * ''[[Seelewig]]'' (1644) of [[Sigmund Staden]], first surviving German opera * ''[[Pomone (opera)]]'' (1671) of [[Robert Cambert]], first French opera (lost) * ''[[Venus and Adonis (opera)]]'' (1683) [[John Blow]], first true English-language opera.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Heinrich Schütz}} {{Apollo and Daphne}}
{{authoritycontrol}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dafne (Opitz-Schutz)}} [[Category:Compositions by Heinrich Schütz]] [[Category:German-language operas]] [[Category:Operas]] [[Category:Pastoral operas]] [[Category:1627 operas]] [[Category:Operas based on Greco-Roman mythology]] [[Category:European court festivities]] [[Category:Lost operas]]

'''Embracery''' is the attempt to influence a [[juror]] [[Political corruption|corruptly]] to give his or her [[verdict]] in favour of one side or the other in a [[trial (law)|trial]], by promise, persuasions, entreaties, money, entertainments and the like.<ref name=EB1911>{{EB1911 |wstitle=Embracery |volume=9 |page=309 |inline=1}}</ref>
In [[English law]], it was an offence both at [[common law]] and by [[statute]], punishable by [[fine (penalty)|fine]] and [[imprisonment]]. As a statutory offence it dates back to 1360. The offence is complete, whether any verdict has been given or not, and whether the verdict is in accordance with the weight of [[evidence (law)|evidence]] or otherwise. The person making the attempt, and any member of the jury who consents, are equally punishable.<ref name=EB1911/>
The legal term "embracery" comes from the [[Old French|Old Fr.]] ''embraseour'', an embracer, i.e., one who excites or instigates, literally one who sets on fire, from ''embraser'', to kindle a fire. This is unrelated to the common word "embrace", i.e., to hold or clasp in the arms, which is from [[French Language|French]] ''embracer'', from [[Latin language|Latin]] ''bracchia'', arms.<ref name=EB1911/>
The false verdict of a jury, whether occasioned by embracery or otherwise, was formerly considered criminal, and jurors were severely punished, being proceeded against by [[writ of attaint]]. The [[Juries Act 1825]], in abolishing writs of attaint, made a special exemption as regards jurors guilty of embracery (s.61). [[Prosecution]] for the offence has been so extremely rare that when a case occurred in 1891<ref>''R v Baker'' 113, Cent. Crim. Ct. Sess. Pap. 374</ref> it was stated that no precedent could be found for the [[indictment]]. The defendant was fined £200, afterwards reduced to £100.<ref name=EB1911/>
By 2010 the offence was regarded as obsolete<ref>{{cite book | author=Richardson, P.J. (ed.) | title=Archbold: Criminal Pleading, Evidence and Practice | year=2006 | publisher=Sweet & Maxwell | location=London | isbn=0-421-90920-X }}, 28-47, 28-151</ref> and such misconduct more likely to be [[criminal charge|charge]]d as [[perverting the course of justice]].<ref>''Attorney-General v. Judd'' [1995] COD 15, DC</ref> The last conviction for embracery in the UK was at Caernarvon [[Crown Court]] in November 1975 but it was quashed by the Court of Appeal the following year on the initiative of [[Frederick Lawton (judge)|Lord Justice Lawton]],<ref>''The Queen -v- Owen'' (1976)3 All ER 229</ref> who said that the offence was obsolete.
The offence was abolished by section 17 of the [[Bribery Act 2010]],<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2010/23/contents Bribery Act 2010] on legislation.gov.uk.</ref> as from 1 July 2011.<ref>[http://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2011/1418/made Bribery Act 2010 (Commencement) Order 2011, SI 2011 No. 1418]</ref>
In the United States, embracery prosecutions have occurred as recently as 1989, when a county commissioner in [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] was sentenced to a fine and probation.<ref>''Calhoun Times''. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=375&dat=19880608&id=62UwAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YjwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2385,8899158 "Embracery Case Politically Motivated, Sutherland Says"]. 8 June 1988, pp. 1A, 2A. Retrieved on 25 June 2013.</ref><ref>''Calhoun Times and Gordon County News''. [https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2213&dat=19890715&id=l0xOAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZzwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5552,826529 "Sutherland Resigns from Board: Gets Probation in Embracery Case"]. 15 July 1989, pp. 1, 3. Retrieved on 25 June 2013.</ref>
==See also== *[[Jury tampering]]
==References== <references/>
