{{Infobox settlement |name = Gabala International Music Festival |settlement_type = |native_name = Qəbələ Musiqi Festivalı |image_skyline = Plakat-festival.jpeg |imagesize = 250px |coordinates = |subdivision_type = Country |subdivision_name = {{flag|Azerbaijan}} |subdivision_name1 = |leader_title = |leader_name = |established_title = |established_date = 2009 |website = http://www.gabalainternationalmusicfestival.com }}
'''Gabala International Music Festival''' is an annual festival of classical music held every summer beginning in 2009 in [[Qabala|Gabala]], [[Azerbaijan]]. The festival is organised with the support of [[Heydar Aliyev Foundation]] at the initiative of the rector of the [[Baku Academy of Music]] [[Farhad Badalbeyli]] and conductor Dmitri Yablonski.<ref>{{Cite news |title = Gabala International Music Festival programme |url = http://www.news.az/articles/19387 |publisher = News.Az |date = 2010-07-20 |accessdate = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100801061045/http://news.az/articles/19387 |archivedate = 2010-08-01 |df = }}</ref> At this festival, musicians perform in the open air. Participants have included musicians from [[Europe]], the [[United States|US]] and [[Israel]], as well as musicians from republics of the former [[Soviet Union|USSR]]. In 2009, a contest of young pianists was held at the same time with the musical festival. [[Jazz]] and [[mugham]] evenings were held along with classical music concerts. In 2010, the festival was held on August. General director of [[UNESCO]] [[Irina Bokova]] was in the opening ceremony of the festival.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Irina Bokova inaugurates the 2nd Gabala International Music Festival in Azerbaijan |url=http://www.unesco.org/new/en/unesco/about-us/who-we-are/director-general/news-single-view/news/irina_bokova_inaugurates_the_2nd_gabala_international_music_festival_in_azerbaijan/ |publisher=UNESCO |date=2010-07-30 |accessdate= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110126221708/http://www.unesco.org/new/en/unesco/about-us/who-we-are/director-general/news-single-view/news/irina_bokova_inaugurates_the_2nd_gabala_international_music_festival_in_azerbaijan/ |archivedate=2011-01-26 |df= }}</ref> The festival began with the performance of overture from [[Uzeyir Hajibeyov|Uzeyir Hajibeyov's]] [[Koroğlu (opera)|"Koroglu" opera]] as in 2009. Opening ceremony of the festival was charged to [[Royal Philharmonic Orchestra|Royal Philarmonic Orchestra]].<ref>{{Cite news |title = Royal Philharmonic Orchestra |url = http://www.gabalainternationalmusicfestival.com/ |publisher = |date = |accessdate = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111113152100/http://www.gabalainternationalmusicfestival.com/ |archivedate = 2011-11-13 |df = }}</ref> Such musicians as Dmitri Yablonski, [[Yuri Bashmet]], Khloe Khanslip and other Azerbaijani and foreign musicians took part in the festival. In 2011, the festival lasted from July 15 to August 5.<ref>{{Cite news | title = Gabala to host third international music festival | url=http://vestnikkavkaza.net/news/culture/15798.html | publisher=Vestnik Kavkaza | date= | accessdate = }}</ref>
== History == Gabala International Music Festival is organized for the first time in 2009, in the city of [[Qabala|Gabala]]. Performances were held by famous musicians from 16 countries such as [[United States|USA]], [[France]], [[Israel]], [[Mexico]], [[Cuba]], [[Poland]], [[Russia]], [[Italy]], [[Spain]] and so forth. In 2010, the festival was held in August and the general director of [[UNESCO]] Irina Bokova attended in the opening ceremony of the festival. The festival started with the overture from Uzeyir Hajibeyov's "Koroglu" opera that was performed by [[Royal Philharmonic Orchestra|Royal Philarmonic Orchestra]] and conducted by professor at the Juilliard School of Music in New York City Oksana Yablonskaya and Azerbaijani conductor Rauf Abdullayev.
In 2011, the festival got started on July 15 and finished on August 5. There was the contest of young pianists which was held in parallel with the musical festival. 21-22 July was the final of Gabala Piano Competition accompanied by Azerbaijan State Symphony Orchestra. On the fifth of August, the closing concert took place with the performance of Orchestra of New Russia. [[Boris Berezovsky (pianist)|Boris Berezovsky]] (in piano) and [[Dmitry Yablonsky]] (as conductor) took part in the festival.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gabalamusicfestival.com/edition-2011|title=GABALA INTERNATIONAL MUSIC FESTIVAL 2011|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The 4th Gabala International Music Festival was held between July 22 and August 5, 2012. The 4th festival opened with a concert dedicated the 70th anniversary of USSR People’s Artist [[Muslim Magomayev (musician)|Muslim Magomayev]] on 24 July, 2012. There were other jubilees dedicated to maestro Niyazi (100) and [[Fikret Amirov|Fikrat Amirov]] (90).<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gabalamusicfestival.com/edition-2012|title=GABALA INTERNATIONAL MUSIC FESTIVAL 2012|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The festival brought together 350 musicians from 10 countries.<ref name=":1" /> The music pieces in the concert were consisted of the works of well-known composers, including Rachmaninoff, Strauss, Brahms, Schumann, Uzeyir Hajibeyli, Tofig Guliyev and Vagif Mustafazade.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://heydar-aliyev-foundation.org/en/content/view/92/37/Gabala-International-Music-Festival-|title=Gabala International Music Festival. Music projects|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>The State Symphonic Orchestra named after U. Hajibeyli, Azerbaijan State Choir Capella, Music Academy Orchestra (Azerbaijan), [[Royal Philharmonic Orchestra]], and Moscow Soloists Chamber Orchestra performed in the festival.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://themoscowtimes.com/articles/bashmet-brings-new-music-festival-to-khabarovsk-13990|title=Bashmet Brings New Music Festival to Khabarovsk.|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The 5th Gabala International Music Festival was held from July 24 to August 6, 2013. Musicians from 11 countries Jerusalem Symphony Orhchestra, New Russia State Symphony Orchestra , the Azerbaijan State Symphonic Orchestra, “Septeto Santiaguero” jazz band, Oksana Yablonskaya soloists Idil Biret, Vadim Repin, Sergey Leyferkus, Farhad Badalbeyli, Dmitri Yablonski and others made a personal contribution to the concert. Within the 5<sup>th</sup> Gabala International Music Festival a chamber music evening was organized to the memory of Sergey Rahmaninov. The closing ceremony performances were held by New Russia State Symphony Orchestra conducted by [[Dmitry Yablonsky]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gabalamusicfestival.com/edition-2013|title=GABALA INTERNATIONAL MUSIC FESTIVAL|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The 6th Gabala International Music Festival took place between July 23 and August 1, 2014. Along with traditional musician and orchestras, the [[Johannesburg Philharmonic Orchestra]], Vienna Chamber Music Ensemble and the representatives from different nations and, such as, USA, [[Ukraine]], Russia, Spain, Israel, and [[Azerbaijan]] participated in the festival. Johannesburg Philharmonic Orchestra, on August 1, played sixteen different compositions from the works of P. Mascagni, G. Verdi, M. Magomayev, G. Rossini, etc.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gabalamusicfestival.com/untitled|title=GABALA INTERNATIONAL MUSIC FESTIVAL 2014 program. PROGRAM/ "VIVA OPERA".|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The 7th Gabala International Music Festival was held on July 25-31, 2015. The festival was accompanied by Chamber orchestra of Weiner Academy (Austria), “Orchestra Filarmonica Italiana”, Kara Karaev State Chamber Orchestra of Azerbaijan, “Moscow Virtuosi”, Dubrovnik - Trio Guitar. The opening concert of the VII Gabala International Music Festival started with the performances of “Orchestra Filarmonica Italiana” on July 25. In the closing concert, Moscow Virtuosi Chamber Orchestra played F. Amirov’s “Nizami” symphony, A. Piazzola’s “4 seasons in Buenos Aires” and other pieces of classical music conducted by [[Dmitry Yablonsky]] (conductor).
The 8th Gabala International Music Festival was organized between July 30 and August 5, 2016. Musicians, art collectives, soloists, conductors from Azerbaijan, Austria, Bulgaria, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, USA, Italy, France, Spain, Israel, Lithuania and Cuba attended in the festival.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://buenosaires.mfa.gov.az/az/news/4/3040|title=VIII Qəbələ Beynəlxalq Musiqi Festivalı keçirilmişdir.|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The Azerbaijan State Symphonic Orchestra named after Uzeyir Hajibeyli, Orchestr Wiener Akademie, Spain’s Suite Española, mugam and folkloric trio from Greece ensemble, Cuban Ensemble “[[Jóvenes Clásicos del Son]]”, Kiev Virtuosi and Israeli composer, conductor and pianist [[Gil Shohat]] and others’ performances constituted a great proportion of concert programme.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gabalamusicfestival.com/edition-2016|title=GABALA INTERNATIONAL MUSIC FESTIVAL (2016)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The 9th Gabala International Music Festival was held from July 29 to August 3, 2017. Student Symphonic Orchestra of Baku Music Academy named after Uzeyir Hajibayli, the Symphonic Orchestra of the Azerbaijan State Academic Opera and Ballet Theater, the British Femusa Chamber Orchestra, and others performed sequentially. Along with Farhad Badalbeyli, Murad Adigozalzadeh, Azer Rzazade, Isfar Sarabski and other Azerbaijanis, Janna Gandelman (Israel), Michael Sladkin (USA), [[Dmitry Yablonsky|Dmitry Yablonski]] (USA), Canluicci Sartori (Italy), Mojca Zlobko Vajgl (Slovenia), Nomeda Kazlaus (Lithuania) and other countries' musicians took part in the festival.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gabalamusicfestival.com/copia-de-edition-2017|title=GABALA INTERNATIONAL MUSIC FESTIVAL (2017)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The 10th Gabala International Music Festival took place between July 30 and August 7, 2018. Chamber concert was held on July 30, in the framework of the project "Youth Support", but July 31 was selected officially as the opening ceremony date. During the festival, Gabala welcomed several orchestras such as Tbilisi City Hall Jazz Orchestra "BIG-BAND (Georgia), Jóvenes Clásicos Del Son (Cuba), Baku Chamber Orchestra (Azerbaijan), Budapest Gypsy Band (Hungary), and [[Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra]] (Israel).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://mct.gov.az/en/regional-news/10th-gabala-international-music-festival-wraps-up|title=10th Gabala International Music Festival wraps up|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.euronews.com/2018/08/08/celebrating-the-gabala-music-festival-in-azerbaijan|title=Deep in the Caucasus Mountains|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://qebele-ih.gov.az/en/news/1098.html|title=The concert of Cuban “Jóvenes Clásicos Del Son” band aroused strong interest within Gabala festival|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.jso.co.il/en/news/the-jso-tours-azerbaijan-and-south-america/|title=The JSO Tours Azerbaijan and South America (2018)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://unitedwithisrael.org/israeli-orchestra-brings-sweet-music-to-muslim-majority-azerbaijan/|title=Israeli Orchestra Brings Sweet Music to Muslim-majority Azerbaijan (August 26, 2018)|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> The festival had several parts. Mugham and multipiano music nights were organized on the 2nd of August.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gabalamusicfestival.com/copia-de-edition-2017|title=GABALA INTERNATIONAL MUSIC FESTIVA 2018|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.jpost.com/Opinion/Azerbaijan-Israel-cultural-partnership-comes-alive-564522|title=AZERBAIJAN-ISRAEL CULTURAL PARTNERSHIP COMES ALIVE|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> On August 5, the chamber music might was dedicated to the 100th anniversary of Azerbaijani composer Gara Garayev. The works of Gara Garayev's “Quartettino” for the string quartet and “Sonata for violin and piano” was performed for the first time in the concert.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /> The final concert of chamber music and the closing ceremony of the festival was took place at the Gabala Culture Center with the performances Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra.<ref name=":4" />
== Concept == Gabala International Music Festivals of (2009-2018) featured international contest of young pianists, concerts of mugham, as well as classic, chamber, jazz, flamenco, vocal music, etc. Every year starting from 2009, musicians from different countries, world-known symphonic and philharmonic orchestras performs in the festival.<ref name=":2" />
== Artistic Directors == Since 2009, [[Farhad Badalbeyli]] is an artistic director of Gabala International Music Festival. Dimitri Yablonsky (music director of Kiev Virtuosi and Conductor Laureate of Jerusalem Symphony Orchestra) is also an organizer of the festival.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gabalamusicfestival.com/founders|title=GABALA INTERNATIONAL MUSIC FESTIVAL. ARTISTICDIRECTORS|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
==Photos== <center> <gallery perrow="6" widths="150px" heights="120px"> Image: Qəbələ 060.jpg Image: Qəbələ666630.jpeg Image: Габала-оркестр.jpeg Image: Габала-фестиваль.jpeg Image: Оркестр-габала.jpeg Image: Рояль-габала.jpeg </gallery> </center>

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{notability|Companies|date=July 2016}} {{cleanup|reason=The lists are too long. See [[WP:IINFO|Wikipedia is not an indiscriminate collection of information.]]|date=July 2016}} }}
The '''International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems (ICORES)''' is an annual conference in the field of [[operations research]]. Two tracks are held simultaneously, covering domain independent methodologies and technologies and also practical work developed in specific application areas. These tracks are present in the conference not only in technical sessions but also in [[poster session]]s, [[keynote]] lectures and [[tutorials]].
The works presented in the conference are published in the conference [[proceedings]] and are made available at the SCITEPRESS [[digital library]]. Usually, it's established a cooperation with [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] for a post-publication with some of the conference best papers.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pinson|first1=Eric|last2=Valente|first2=Fernando|last3=Vitoriano|first3=Begoña|title=Operations Research and Enterprise Systems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cTY3CwAAQBAJ|publisher=Springer|accessdate=22 July 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=de Werra|first1=Dominique|last2=Parlier|first2=Greg H.|last3=Vitoriano|first3=Begoña|title=Operations Research and Enterprise Systems|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cTY3CwAAQBAJ|publisher=Springer|accessdate=22 July 2016}}</ref> The first edition of ICORES was held in 2012 in conjunction with the International Conference on Agents and Artificial Intelligence ([[ICAART]]) and the International Conference on Pattern Recognition Applications and Methods ([[ICPRAM]]).
==Areas==
===Methodologies and Technologies=== * [[Stochastic optimization]] * [[Systems of systems]] * [[Simulation]] * [[Optimization]] * [[Game Theory]] * [[Management sciences]] * [[Information Systems]] * [[Industrial Engineering]]
===Applications=== * OR in Health * [[Decision Support Systems]] * [[Supply Chain Management]] * [[Resource Allocation]] * [[Project Management]] * [[Logistics]] * [[Risk Management]]
==Current Chairs==
===Conference Chair=== Marc Demange, School of Science, Mathematical and Geospatial Sciences, [[RMIT University]], Australia
===Program Co-Chairs=== * Greg H. Parlier, [[INFORMS]], United States * Federico Liberatore, [[Universidad Carlos III de Madrid]], Spain
==Editions==
===ICORES 2016 - Lisbon, Portugal === Proceedings - Proceedings of the International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems. {{ISBN|978-989-758-171-7}} <ref>{{cite web|title=ICORES 2016 dblp information|url=http://dblp.uni-trier.de/search?q=ICORES%202016|website=dblp.uni-trier.de}}</ref>
==== Best Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - Yujie Chen, Fiona Polack, Peter Cowling, Philip Mourdjis and Stephen Remde. "Risk Driven Analysis of Maintenance for a Large-scale Drainage System"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Risk Driven Analysis of Maintenance for a Large-scale Drainage System|doi=10.5220/0005749102960303|journal=Proceedings of the 5th International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
''Area: Methodologies and Technologies'' - Vikas Vikram Singh, Oualid Jouini and Abdel Lisser. "A Complementarity Problem Formulation for Chance-constraine Games"<ref>{{cite journal|title=A Complementarity Problem Formulation for Chance-constraine Games|doi=10.5220/0005754800580067|journal=Proceedings of the 5th International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
==== Best Student Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - Jose L. Saez and Victor M. Albornoz. "Delineation of Rectangular Management Zones Under Uncertainty Conditions"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Delineation of Rectangular Management Zones Under Uncertainty Conditions|doi=10.5220/0005708202710278|journal=Proceedings of the 5th International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
==== Best PhD Project Award ==== Parisa Madhooshiarzanagh. "Preference Dissagrigation Model of ELECTRE TRI-NC and Its Application on Identifying Preferred Climates for Tourism".
===ICORES 2015 - Lisbon, Portugal === Proceedings - Proceedings of the International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems. {{ISBN|978-989-758-075-8}} <ref>{{cite web|title=ICORES 2015 dblp information|url=http://dblp.uni-trier.de/search?q=ICORES+2015|website=dblp.uni-trier.de}}</ref>
==== Best Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - L. Berghman, C. Briand, R. Leus and P. Lopez. "The Truck Scheduling Problem at Crossdocking Terminals"<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Truck Scheduling Problem at Crossdocking Terminals|doi=10.5220/0005205102470253|journal=Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems|url=https://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/hal-01230870/file/Crossdocking-PL-5.pdf}}</ref>
''Area: Methodologies and Technologies'' - Kailiang Xu and Gang Zheng. "Schedule Two-machine Flow-shop with Controllable Processing Times Using Tabu-search"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Schedule Two-machine Flow-shop with Controllable Processing Times Using Tabu-search|doi=10.5220/0005204300140022|journal=Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
==== Best Student Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - Wasakorn Laesanklang, Dario Landa-Silva and J. Arturo Castillo Salazar. "Mixed Integer Programming with Decomposition to Solve a Workforce Scheduling and Routing Problem"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Mixed Integer Programming with Decomposition to Solve a Workforce Scheduling and Routing Problem|doi=10.5220/0005223602830293|journal=Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
''Area: Methodologies and Technologies'' - Jan Bok and Milan Hladík. "Selection-based Approach to Cooperative Interval Games"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Selection-based Approach to Cooperative Interval Games|doi=10.5220/0005221600340041|journal=Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems|arxiv=1410.3877}}</ref>
==== Best PhD Project Award ==== Nigel M. Clay, John Hearne, Babak Abbasi and Andrew Eberhard. "Ensuring Blood is Available When it is Needed Most"
Sandy Jorens, Annelies De Corte, Kenneth Sörensen and Gunther Steenackers. "The Air Distribution Network Design Problem - A Complex Non-linear Combinatorial Optimization Problem "
===ICORES 2014 - ESEO, Angers, Loire Valley, France=== Proceedings - Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems. {{ISBN|978-989-758-017-8}} <ref>{{cite web|title=ICORES 2014 dblp information|url=http://dblp.uni-trier.de/search?q=ICORES+2014|website=dblp.uni-trier.de}}</ref>
==== Best Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - Céline Gicquel and Michel Minoux. "New Multi-product Valid Inequalities for a Discrete Lot-sizing Problem"<ref>{{cite journal|title=New Multi-product Valid Inequalities for a Discrete Lot-sizing Problem|doi=10.5220/0004751703550362|journal=Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
''Area: Methodologies and Technologies'' - Nadia Chaabane Fakhfakh, Cyril Briand and Marie-José Huguet. "A Multi-Agent Min-Cost Flow problem with Controllable Capacities"<ref>{{cite journal|title=A Multi-Agent Min-Cost Flow problem with Controllable Capacities|doi=10.5220/0004765500270034|journal=Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
==== Best Student Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - Nhat-Vinh Vo, Pauline Fouillet and Christophe Lenté. "General Lower Bounds for the Total Completion Time in a Flowshop Scheduling Problem"<ref>{{cite journal|title=General Lower Bounds for the Total Completion Time in a Flowshop Scheduling Problem|doi=10.5220/0004833403820389|journal=Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
''Area: Methodologies and Technologies'' - António Quintino, João Carlos Lourenço and Margarida Catalão-Lopes. "Managing Price Risk for an Oil and Gas Company"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Managing Price Risk for an Oil and Gas Company|doi=10.5220/0004856901270138|journal=Proceedings of the 3rd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
==== Best PhD Project Award ==== Laura Wagner and Mustafa Çagri Gürbüz. "Sourcing Decisions for Goods with Potentially Imperfect Quality under the Presence of Supply Disruption "
===ICORES 2013 - Barcelona, Spain=== Proceedings - Proceedings of the 2nd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems. {{ISBN|978-989-8565-40-2}} <ref>{{cite web|title=ICORES 2013 dblp information|url=http://dblp.uni-trier.de/search?q=ICORES+2013|website=dblp.uni-trier.de}}</ref>
==== Best Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - Daniel Reich, Sandra L. Winkler and Erica Klampfl. "The Pareto Frontier for Vehicle Fleet Purchases"<ref>{{cite journal|title=The Pareto Frontier for Vehicle Fleet Purchases|doi=10.5220/0004222901750182|journal=Proceedings of the 2nd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
''Area: Methodologies and Technologies'' - N. Perel, J. L. Dorsman and M. Vlasiou. "Cyclic-type Polling Models with Preparation Times"<ref>{{cite journal|title=Cyclic-type Polling Models with Preparation Times|doi=10.5220/0004206500140023|journal=Proceedings of the 2nd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
==== Best Student Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - Ahmad Almuhtady, Seungchul Lee, Edwin Romeijn and Jun Ni. "A Maintenance-optimal Swapping Policy"<ref>{{cite journal|title=A Maintenance-optimal Swapping Policy|doi=10.5220/0004270601830192|journal=Proceedings of the 2nd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
''Area: Methodologies and Technologies'' - Pablo Adasme, Abdel Lisser and Chen Wang. "A Distributionally Robust Formulation for Stochastic Quadratic Bi-level Programming"<ref>{{cite journal|title=A Distributionally Robust Formulation for Stochastic Quadratic Bi-level Programming|doi=10.5220/0004207100240031|journal=Proceedings of the 2nd International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
===ICORES 2012 - Vilamoura, Algarve, Portugal === Proceedings - Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems. {{ISBN|978-989-8425-97-3}} <ref>{{cite web|title=ICORES 2012 dblp information|url=http://dblp.uni-trier.de/search?q=ICORES+2012|website=dblp.uni-trier.de}}</ref>
==== Best Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - Rita Macedo, Saïd Hanafi, François Clautiaux, Cláudio Alves and J. M. Valério de Carvalho. "GENERALIZED DISAGGREGATION ALGORITHM FOR THE VEHICLE ROUTING PROBLEM WITH TIME WINDOWS AND MULTIPLE ROUTES"<ref>{{cite journal|title=GENERALIZED DISAGGREGATION ALGORITHM FOR THE VEHICLE ROUTING PROBLEM WITH TIME WINDOWS AND MULTIPLE ROUTES|doi=10.5220/0003755003050312|journal=Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
''Area: Methodologies and Technologies'' - Herwig Bruneel, Willem Mélange, Bart Steyaert, Dieter Claeys and Joris Walraevens. "IMPACT OF BLOCKING WHEN CUSTOMERS OF DIFFERENT CLASSES ARE ACCOMMODATED IN ONE COMMON QUEUE"<ref>{{cite journal|title=IMPACT OF BLOCKING WHEN CUSTOMERS OF DIFFERENT CLASSES ARE ACCOMMODATED IN ONE COMMON QUEUE|doi=10.5220/0003735500310038|journal=Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
==== Best Student Paper Award ==== ''Area: Applications'' - Jianqiang Cheng, Stefanie Kosuch and Abdel Lisser. "STOCHASTIC SHORTEST PATH PROBLEM WITH UNCERTAIN DELAYS"<ref>{{cite journal|title=STOCHASTIC SHORTEST PATH PROBLEM WITH UNCERTAIN DELAYS|doi=10.5220/0003725102560264|journal=Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
''Area: Methodologies and Technologies'' - A. Papayiannis, P. Johnson, D. Yumashev, S. Howell, N. Proudlove and P. Duck. "CONTINUOUS-TIME REVENUE MANAGEMENT IN CARPARKS"<ref>{{cite journal|title=CONTINUOUS-TIME REVENUE MANAGEMENT IN CARPARKS|doi=10.5220/0003762800730082|journal=Proceedings of the 1st International Conference on Operations Research and Enterprise Systems}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.scitevents.com/Search/AdvancedSearchGeneral?searchTermSite=ICORES&x=0&y=0 Science and Technology Events] * [http://www.icores.org/ Conference website] * [http://www.scitepress.org/DigitalLibrary/ProceedingsList.aspx?FieldName=NX8zK3c48nE=&t=1&title=7+mgmp501Xk=&t=1&conference=4MYkT2fcaBg=&t=1&year=7+mgmp501Xk=&t=1&isbn=7+mgmp501Xk=&t=1 Science and Technology Publications] * [http://www.insticc.org/Primoris/ Event management system] * [http://www.wikicfp.com/cfp/servlet/tool.search?q=ICORES&year=a WikiCfp call for papers]
[[Category:Operations research]] [[Category:Modeling and simulation]] [[Category:Computer science conferences]] [[Category:Academic conferences]]

{{BLP sources|date=August 2018}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Jennifer Ringley | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jennifer Kaye Ringley | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1976|8|10}} | birth_place = [[Harrisburg, Pennsylvania|Harrisburg]], [[Pennsylvania]], U.S. | other_names = Jennifer Johnson | death_date = | death_place = | spouse = | relations = | years_active = 1996–2003 | notable_works = | known_for = ''JenniCam''
[[Lifecasting (video stream)|Lifecasting]] | website = {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031227221244/http://www.jennicam.org:80/|date=December 27, 2003|title=jennicam.org}} }} '''Jennifer Kaye Ringley''' (born August 10, 1976){{cite web |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19971210110509/http://www.boudoir.org/faq/jenni.html |title=Frequently Asked Questions |publisher=JenniCam |archivedate=December 10, 1997 |deadurl=yes |accessdate=May 8, 2011 |first=Jennifer |last=Ringley |url=http://www.boudoir.org/faq/jenni.html}} is an [[Internet celebrity|Internet personality]] and former [[Lifecasting (video stream)|lifecaster]]. She is known for creating the popular website '''JenniCam'''.{{cite web |url=http://www.hollywoodpa.com/subpages/productionoffice/castandcrew/talent/jenni1.html |title=Jennifer Ringley |publisher=Hollywood, PA}} Previously, live webcams transmitted static shots from cameras aimed through windows or [[Trojan Room coffee pot|at coffee pots]]. Ringley's innovation was simply to allow others to view her daily activities. She was the first web-based "lifecaster".{{Cite book |chapter=Branding the Post-feminist Self:: Girls' Video Production and YouTube |last=Banet-Weider |first=Sarah |publisher=[[Peter Lang (publisher)|Peter Lang]] |year=2013 |isbn=9781433105616 |location=New York |pages=51–71 |title=Mediated Girlhoods: New Explorations of Girls' Media Culture |editor-first=Mary Celeste |editor-last=Kearney}} In June 2008, CNET hailed JenniCam as one of the greatest defunct websites in history.{{cite web |url=http://crave.cnet.co.uk/0,39029477,49296926-2,00.htm |title=The greatest defunct Web sites and dotcom disasters |publisher=[[CNET]] |date=June 5, 2008 |accessdate=June 5, 2008 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080607211819/http://crave.cnet.co.uk/0%2C39029477%2C49296926-2%2C00.htm |archivedate=June 7, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }} She retired from lifecasting at the end of 2003. ==JenniCam== Regarded by some as a [[conceptual art]]ist,{{cite web |title=Forgotten Web Celebrities: Jennicam.org's Jennifer Ringley |url=http://www.disobey.com/ghostsites/2004_05_19_archive.html |accessdate=March 27, 2014 |date=May 19, 2004 |first=Steve |last=Baldwin |publisher=Disobey.com: Content for the discontented (blog)}} Ringley viewed her site as a straightforward document of her life.{{cite web |url=http://cgd.best.vwh.net/home/naturism/wnl-0101.htm#commentary |title=Commentary: JenniCam |work=The Weekly Nudesletter |first=Charles |last=Daney |date=September 29, 1997 |volume=1 |number=1}} She did not wish to filter the events that were shown on her camera, so sometimes she was shown [[Nudity|nude]] or engaging in sexual behavior, including [[Coitus|sexual intercourse]] and [[masturbation]]. This was a new use of Internet technology in 1996 and some viewers were interested in its sociological implications while others watched it for sexual arousal. The JenniCam website coincided with a rise in surveillance as a feature of popular culture, exemplified by the 1998 film ''[[The Truman Show]]'' and reality television programs such as ''[[Big Brother (TV series)|Big Brother]]'', and as a feature of contemporary art and new media art. From a sociological point of view, JenniCam was an important early example of how the internet could create a cyborg subject by integrating human images with the internet. As such, JenniCam set the stage for conversations regarding the relationship of technology and gender.{{cite journal |last=Jimroglou |first=Krissi M. |title=A camera with a view: JenniCAM, visual representation, and cyborg subjectivity |journal=Information, Communication & Society |year=1999 |volume=2 |issue=4 |page=439 |doi=10.1080/136911899359493}} Ringley's desire to maintain the purity of the cam-eye view of her life eventually created the need to establish that she was within her rights as an adult to broadcast such information, in the legal sense, and that it was not harmful to other adults. Unlike later for-profit webcam services,{{cite web |title=Webcam Models |url=http://www.pandoramodeling.com/the-pay-scale |accessdate=March 24, 2014 |year=2014 |publisher=Pandora Modelling |first=Jordan |last=Keith |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140109231404/http://www.pandoramodeling.com/the-pay-scale |archive-date=January 9, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} Ringley did not spend her day displaying her naked body and she spent much more time discussing her romantic life than she did her sex life.{{cite news |url=http://archive.salon.com/tech/log/2000/08/04/jennicam/index.html |title=Jenni's in love |date=August 8, 2000 |work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |first=Alice |last=Lipowicz |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031026141953/http://archive.salon.com/tech/log/2000/08/04/jennicam/index.html |archive-date=October 26, 2003 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |url=http://archive.salon.com/21st/feature/1998/01/cov_08feature.html |title=21st: Live! From my bedroom |date=January 8, 1998 |work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |author= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031013022202/http://archive.salon.com/21st/feature/1998/01/cov_08feature.html |archive-date=October 13, 2003 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} Ringley maintained her webcam site for seven years and eight months.{{cite web |url=http://slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=03/12/05/0536233 |title=JenniCam Closing After 7+ Years |date=December 31, 2003 |website=[[slashdot]]}} Sources stated that JenniCam received over 100 million visitors weekly. Nate Lanxon of ''[[CNET]]'' said "remember this is 1996 and the Web as we know it now had barely lost its virginity, let alone given birth to the God-child we know as the modern Internet."{{cite news |last=Lanxon |first=Nate |title=The greatest defunct Web sites and dotcom disasters. |work=[[CNET]] |date=June 5, 2008 |url=http://crave.cnet.co.uk/gadgets/the-greatest-defunct-web-sites-and-dotcom-disasters-49296926/2/ |accessdate=May 13, 2011}} ===Origins=== On April 3, 1996, during her junior year at [[Dickinson College]] in [[Carlisle, Pennsylvania]], the 19-year-old Ringley installed a webcam in her college [[dorm]] room and provided images from that cam on a [[webpage]].{{cite web |url=http://www.amazing.com/jennifer/ |title=Jennifer Ringley doesn't live here anymore ... |first=David H |last=Dennis |work=Amazing (blog) |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040605013816/http://www.amazing.com/jennifer/ |archive-date=June 5, 2004 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} The webpage would automatically refresh every three minutes with the most recent picture from the camera. Initially, anyone with Internet access could observe the often mundane events of Ringley's life; however, a few months after its start, Ringley started charging viewers for full entry to her site. JenniCam was one of the first web sites that continuously and voluntarily surveyed a private life. Her first webcam contained only black-and-white images of her in the dorm room. JenniCam attracted up to four million views a day at its peak. At times during the first couple of years of JenniCam, Ringley performed stripteases for the webcam.{{cite web |url=http://www.metamute.org/editorial/articles/story-eye |title=The Story of the Eye |date=September 9, 1997 |first=Hari |last=Kunzru |work=[[Mute (magazine)|Mute]]}} This continued until an incident occurred wherein she was discovered by a group of hackers on Efnet who teased her for their own amusement. After she reacted humorously to their taunts, JenniCam was [[Hacker (computer security)|hacked]], and Ringley received death threats.{{cite web |url=http://www.usd.edu/~rbirgen/Joe/JKR.html |title=Jennifer Kaye Ringley |first=Joseph John James |last=Birgen |work=Gremlin (blog) |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040611190704/http://www.usd.edu/~rbirgen/Joe/JKR.html |archive-date=June 11, 2004 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} The hackers turned out to be approximately 100 people including a handful of teen pranksters,{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/SHOWBIZ/Movies/9903/26/jennicam/ |title='Ed' of the Internet: JenniCAM going strong after three years |date=March 26, 1999 |work=[[CNN]] |first=Jamie |last=Allen}} but Ringley did no more stripteases after that. Initially, the camera tended to be turned off during especially private moments, but eventually this custom was abandoned, and images were captured of Ringley engaging in sex. In May 1997, Ringley graduated from Dickinson with a Bachelor of Arts in Economics. ===Washington D.C.=== When Ringley moved to Washington, D.C. in 1998, she added webcams to cover the additional living space (four webcams captured images of her life). She began charging for access to her site, allowing both paid and free access with the paid access updating the images more frequently than the free access. She added more pages to her website that included pictures of her cats and ferrets. Her site was doing well as she stayed home and claimed her profession to be a "[[web designer]]" for her site. As Ringley attracted a following both on and off the Internet, more than 100 media outlets from ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' to ''Modern Ferret'' ran features. Ringley owned several [[ferret]]s and ''Modern Ferret'' featured Jenni and one of her pets on the front cover.{{cite news |url=http://www.modernferret.com/mfm028/index.html |magazine=Modern Ferret |number=28 |title=Chatting with Jennicam |author= |date= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031217120712/http://modernferret.com/mfm028/index.html |archive-date=December 17, 2003 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} As an actress, she was cast in "[[Rear Windows '98]]," a 1998 episode of the TV series ''[[Diagnosis Murder]]'', portraying Joannecam, a fictionalized version of herself. She also hosted her own Internet talk show titled The Jennishow{{cite web |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1999/02/16/the-moving-pixel-show/dd3308e0-892e-4f07-99a6-d27fd92de931/?utm_term=.239664884fb6 |newspaper=The Washington Post |title=The Moving Pixel Show |date=16 February 1998}} on [[The Sync]], an early webcasting network based in [[Laurel, Maryland]]. Ringley's standard of living improved with a new larger apartment, expensive furniture and several business trips to [[Amsterdam]] with her accountant. She claimed that the experience improved her self-image and self body image.{{cite web |url=http://www.jspace.org/jennireuters |title=Jennifer Ringley is her own paparazzi |date=September 22, 1997 |work=j-space (blog) |first=Jake |last=Savin}} Ringley began to take trips to visit other cam girls, including [[Ana Voog]] of Anacam.com. At the height of her popularity, an estimated three to four million people watched JenniCam.org daily. She eventually purchased the domain jennicam.com as well. She appeared July 31, 1998 as a guest on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]''. At the end of the interview, and even after having been corrected once, Letterman plugged the site as Jennicam.net instead of the correct Jennicam.com (Ringley owned both Jennicam.com and Jennicam.org). People visiting the previously non-existent Jennicam.net found a pornographic site with the greeting, "Thanks Dave". She also appeared on ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'' and ''[[World News Tonight With Peter Jennings]]''.{{cite web |url=http://www.thesync.com/wcfs/ |title=Harmful to Minors Law Going to Court in New Mexico |work=Webcasters Coalition for Free Speech |date=September 21, 1999 |author= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040621002402/http://thesync.com/wcfs/ |archive-date=June 21, 2004 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} In 1999, clips from The Jennishow were included in the [[Museum of Modern Art]]'s exhibition "Fame After Photography." {{cite web |url=https://www.moma.org/documents/moma_press-release_386987.pdf |title=PROVOCATIVE EXHIBITION AT MOMA TRACES THE COMPLEX CONNECTIONS BETWEEN PHOTOGRAPHY AND FAME |date=June 1999}} ===Sacramento=== When Ringley moved to [[Sacramento, California]], she documented the boxing of her possessions with free live streaming and full audio. Ringley received some criticism from fans when she became involved with Dex, a man who was the fiancé of a fellow webcammer and friend who helped her move to California.{{cite web |url=http://www.gettingit.com/article/758 |title=Little Jenni Homewrecker: Web vixen gets shot by her own cam |date=July 27, 2000 |first=Lou |last=Cabron |work=GettingIt |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040623031455/http://www.gettingit.com/article/758 |archive-date=June 23, 2004 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} She shut down her site on December 31, 2003, citing [[PayPal]]'s new anti-nudity policy.{{cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2003/12/12/BUG3U3LP7J1.DTL |title=Curtains in the bedroom – JenniCam switches off |date=December 12, 2003 |newspaper=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |first=Todd |last=Wallack}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/magazine/3360063.stm |title=R.I.P. JenniCam |date=January 1, 2004 |work=[[BBC News]]}}{{cite web |url=http://cfserv.dickinson.edu/dickinsonian/detail.cfm?183 |title=Good-bye, JenniCam ... |date=December 12, 2003 |newspaper=[[The Dickinsonian]] |first=John |last=Merriman |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20040510201323/http://cfserv.dickinson.edu/dickinsonian/detail.cfm?183 |archive-date=May 10, 2004 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }}{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/2003/TECH/internet/12/10/jenni.cam.reut/ |title=Voyeur Web site JenniCam to go dark |date=December 10, 2003 |work=[[CNN]]}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2003/12/10/reg_seeks_poetic_jennicam_memorial/ |title=Reg seeks poetic JenniCam memorial |date=December 10, 2003 |work=[[The Register]] |first=Lester |last=Haines}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nationalreview.com/comment/teachout200312110800.asp |title=Jenni’s Footnote |date=December 11, 2003 |magazine=[[National Review]]}} ==After JenniCam== Since the end of 2003, Ringley has avoided having a presence on the Internet and on [[social media]] and tries to stay out of public spotlight. Ringley worked for a web developer after a brief stint as a case worker for a social services agency in Sacramento. Out of the public eye, she stated, "I really am enjoying my privacy now. I don't have a web page; I don't have a MySpace page. It's a completely different feeling, and I think I'm enjoying it.""Behind the Scenes with Jennifer Ringley", segment of "Webjunk" on [[VH1]], posted to IFILM on March 18, 2007. In December 2014, Ringley spoke to the podcast [[Reply All (podcast)|Reply All]] about her experiences with Jennicam; the podcast noted that Jenny "is almost entirely absent from the Internet ... just the way she likes it."{{cite podcast |url=http://gimletmedia.com/episode/5-the-jennicam/ |title=#5 Jennicam |series=[[Reply All (podcast)|Reply All]] |number=5 |date=December 17, 2014 |publisher=[[Gimlet Media]]}} In a rare 2016 interview with the [[BBC]], Ringley described herself as a programmer in California and married to a man with the very common surname of [[Johnson]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-37681006 |publisher=[[BBC News]] |title=Jennicam: The first woman to stream her life on the internet |date=October 18, 2016 |first=Aleks |last=Krotoski}}{{cite episode |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b07z414z |title=Jennifer |series=The Digital Human |network=[[BBC]] |station=[[BBC Radio 4]] |season=10 |airdate=17 October 2016 |first=Aleks |last=Krotoski}}{{cite news |last1=Alptraum |first1=Lux |title=There Is Life After Campus Infamy |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/07/21/style/campus-sex-women-exposure.html |accessdate=22 July 2018 |publisher=New York Times |date=22 July 2018}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * {{cite book |title=Feminist Cyberscapes: Mapping Gendered Academic Spaces |last1=Blair |first1=K. |last2=Takayoshi |first2=P.|isbn=1-56750-438-8 |publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group |year=1999 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RH54pe0aH50C&dq=1567504388&pg=PA8&lpg=PA8&q=jennicam#v=onepage&q=jennicam&f=false}} * {{cite journal |title=Jenni's Room: Exhibitionism and Solitude |last=Burgin |first=V. |journal=[[Critical Inquiry]] |year=2000 |volume=27 |number=1 |pages=77-89 |jstor=1344228}} * {{cite book |chapter=Gender and power in online communication |last=Herring |first=S.C. |title=The Handbook of Language and Gender |year=2003 |doi=10.1002/9780470756942.ch9 |editor-first1=Janet |editor-last1=Holmes |editor-first2=Miriam |editor-last2=Meyerhoff |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]]}} * {{cite journal |url=http://blog.lib.umn.edu/swiss/archive/Jimroglou.pdf |title=A camera with a view: JenniCAM, visual representation, and cyborg subjectivity |last=Jimroglou |first=K. M. |journal=Information Communication and Society |volume=2 |number=4 |pages=439–453 |year=1999 |doi=10.1080/136911899359493}} * {{cite book |title=tekst.no : strukturer og sjangrer i digitale medier |last1=Schwebs |first1=Ture |last2=Otnes |first2=Hildegunn |page=175 |location=Oslo |publisher=Cappelen |isbn=82-02-19673-6 |year=2001 |language=no |trans-title=Text.no: Structures and genres in digital media}} * {{cite journal |title=Design vs. Content: A Survey of Ten Popular Web Sites That Made Emotional Connections with the User |last=Vogler |first=D. |journal=Computers in Entertainment (CIE) |year=2005 |volume=3 |issue=2 |page=4 |publisher=[[Association for Computing Machinery]] |doi=10.1145/1063723.1063734}} * {{cite news |title=JenniCam's So-called Life Goes Live |work=[[Washington Business Journal]] |date=January 19, 1998 |first=Thomas C. |last=Hall |url=https://www.bizjournals.com/washington/stories/1998/01/19/tidbits.html}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/*/http://jennicam.org Archive.org for jennicam.org] ===Interviews=== * {{cite episode |url=https://www.thisamericanlife.org/radio-archives/episode/66/tales-from-the-net |series=[[This American Life]] |title=Tales from the Net |number=66 |minutes=16 |quote=Conversation with Jennifer Ringley |network=[[NPR]]}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|id=1478850|name=Jennifer Ringley}} * [http://www.arttech.ab.ca/pbrown/jenni/jenni.html JenniCam Archive] * [https://web.archive.org/*/http://www.jennicam.org/ Jennicam] (Archive) * [https://web.archive.org/*/http://www.boudoir.org/ Jennicam at boudoir.org] (Archive) * [http://blog.worshiptheglitch.com/post/29136828967/2007-02-jennishow-episodes-41-43-html All 43 Episodes of JenniShow] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0AmIntaD5VE Jennifer Ringley appearance on ''The Late Show with David Letterman''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Jennicam}} [[Category:1976 births|Ringley, Jennifer {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person |image =KOCHOUSEPH CHITTILAPPILLY.jpg | caption = Chittilappily in 2011 | birth_date = 1950 | birth_place = Parappur, [[Thrissur]], [[Kerala]], [[India]] | residence = [[Edappally]], [[Kochi]], [[India]]{{cite news|title=A curious turn to Jazeera’s struggle|url=https://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Kochi/a-curious-turn-to-jazeeras-struggle/article5652174.ece|date=4 February 2014 | newspaper=[[The Hindu]] | accessdate=27 August 2018 }} | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Businessperson, writer | known_for = [[Business]]
Philanthropy
Humanism | children = Arun Chittilappilly
Mithun Chittilappilly | parents = C. O. Thomas | awards = [[Government of India|GOI]] Rashtriya Samman
Millennium Businessman of Kerala
Tourism Man of the Year 2000
[[Newsmaker of the Year (Manorama News)|Newsmaker of the Year]] 2011
TMA Manager of the Year 2000
ATTOI Tourism Man of the Year 2011 | website = {{Url|http://www.kochousephchittilappilly.com|kochousephchittilappilly.com}} | restingplace = | restingplacecoordinates = | othername = | alma mater = [[St. Thomas College, Thrissur]]
(MSc in Physics) | yearsactive = | spouse = Sheila Chittilappilly | domesticpartner = }} '''Kochouseph Thomas Chittilappilly''' is an [[India]]n [[business magnate]], writer,{{cite web | url=https://www.amazon.com/s/ref=dp_byline_sr_book_1?ie=UTF8&text=Kochouseph+Chittilappilly&search-alias=books&field-author=Kochouseph+Chittilappilly&sort=relevancerank | title=Amazon profile | publisher=Amazon | date=2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} [[investor]] and philanthropist.{{cite web | url=http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2011-05-22/news/29569008_1_v-guard-industries-kidneys-kochouseph-chittilappilly | title=Kochouseph Chittilappilly: Founder of V-Guard Industries does 'unconventional' things | publisher=Economic Times | date=22 May 2011 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} He is the founder,{{cite web|title=Kochouseph Thomas Chittilappilly|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=33404075&ticker=VGRD:IN|publisher=[[Business Week]]}} Chairman and [[Chief Executive Officer]]{{cite web | url=http://www.indianexpress.com/news/businessman-donates-kidney-to-truck-driver-sets-off-chain-reaction/739139/ | title=Businessman donates kidney to truck driver, sets off chain reaction | date=19 January 2011 | accessdate=8 October 2015 | author=Shaju Philip | newspaper=The Indian Express}} of [[V-Guard Industries Ltd]]{{cite web | url=http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/Against+the+current/1/21167.html | title=Against the current : UNUSUAL ENTREPRENEURS—INNOVATORS | date=28 Nov 2008 | author=M.G. Radhakrishnan | newspaper=India Today}} and a chain of amusement parks called [[Wonderla]].{{cite web | url=http://www.vguard.in/about-us/founder-profile | title=Founder's profile | publisher=V Guard | date=2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} ''K. Chittilappilly Foundation'', a non profit organization founded by him is engaged in charitable and philanthropic activities.{{cite web | url=http://kcfoundation.in/about-us.php | title=K Chittilappilly Foundation | publisher=K Chittilappilly Foundation | date=2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} Chittilappilly is a recipient of the ''Rashtriya Samman'' award from the [[Government of India]] for being among the highest taxpayers{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=33404075&ticker=VGRD:IN | title=Bloomberg profile | publisher=Bloomberg | date=2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} and the ''Newsmaker of the Year 2011'' award from [[Malayala Manorama]].{{cite web | url=http://www.ndtv.com/kerala-news/v-guard-md-selected-as-newsmaker-of-the-year-2011-567889 | title=V Guard MD selected as 'Newsmaker of the Year 2011 | publisher=NDTV | date=9 January 2012 | accessdate=12 August 2015}} As the chairman of the Stray Dog Free movement, he has advocated for government action to address the "menace" of [[stray dog]]s in his home state of [[Kerala]], and has criticized legislation forbidding the killing of stray dogs. ==Biography== Kochouseph Chittilappilly was born to C. O. Thomas in [[Parappur]], a suburb of [[Thrissur]] in the south Indian state of Kerala in 1950.{{cite web | url=http://www.leadersofkerala.com/documents/Biography/43_43.pdf | title=Leaders of Kerala profile | publisher=Leaders of Kerala | date=2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} His early schooling was at the local church school after which he graduated from [[Christ College, Irinjalakuda]] and followed it with a master's degree in Physics from [[St. Thomas College, Thrissur]] in 1970. His career kick started in 1973 at Telics, a [[Thiruvananthapuram]] based electronics company manufacturing voltage stabilizers and emergency lamps, in the capacity of a supervisor where he worked for three years. In 1977, he founded [[V-Guard Industries Ltd|V-Guard Industries]], a small electronics manufacturing unit for the production of voltage stabilizers with a capital of {{INR}}100,000. The company which had 2 employees at its modest manufacturing facility in [[Thrissur]] at inception, grew over the years to become the largest selling stabilizer brand in India.{{cite web | url=https://www.valueresearchonline.com/story/h2_storyView.asp?str=26062 | title=Stabilising Effect | publisher=Value Research Online | date=2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} The company claims to have 500 distributors, 3000 dealers, 20,000 retailers and a network of service centres across India{{cite web | url=http://www.vguard.in/about-us/story | title=V-Guard Story | publisher=V-Guard | date=2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} supporting a product range composed of Pumps and Motors, Electric and Solar Water Heaters, Wiring Cables, UPS, and Ceiling Fans. The company has an Indian market share of 20 percent in UPS segment, 15 percent in pumps, 12 percent in water heaters and 7 percent in wiring cables segments. Chittilapilly is reported to have introduced a new business model by total product outsourcing coupled with in-house quality control when his factories were shut down following a workers' strike in the 1980s. Later, diversifying the business, he started the first water theme park in the state of Kerala under the name, ''Veegaland'', in 2000. Another park on a larger scale, [[Wonderla]], was subsequently started in [[Bengaluru]]. Veegaland has since been renamed as Wonderla Kochi, in an effort to establish the name as a brand.{{cite web | url=http://www.dakshinroutes.com/Tour-Packages/kochouseph-chittilappilly.aspx | title=Dakshin Personality of the Month | publisher=Dakshin Routes | date=2015 | accessdate=12 August 2015}}{{cite web | url=http://www.wonderla.com/kochi-amusement-park/ | title=Wonderla Kochi | publisher=Wonderla Kochi | date=2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} Veegaland Developers is another venture by Kochouseph Chittillappilly that is in to construction of ready to occupy flats and apartments in Cochin Chittilapilly is married to Sheila and the couple has two sons Arun Chittilappilly and Mithun Chittilappilly. Sheila is the Managing Director of [[V-Star Creations]], a group company. Arun heads the amusement park business, [[Wonderla]] and Mithun is the incumbent Managing Director of [[V-Guard Industries]]. ==Writing career== Chittilappilly published his first book, ''Practical Wisdom'', in 2005, which is an account of practical management techniques he derived from his personal experiences.{{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.com/Practical-Wisdom-Kochouseph-Chittilappilly/dp/B007E4Y8NA | title=Practical Wisdom | publisher=DC Books | author=Kochouseph Chittilappilly | year=2005 | ASIN=B007E4Y8NA}} Two more books in the same series followed, Practical Wisdom 1: In Real Life and Management (2010){{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.com/Practical-Wisdom-Real-Life-Management/dp/813092398X/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1439303527&sr=1-1 | title=Practical Wisdom 1: In Real Life and Management | publisher=Viva Books | author=Kochouseph Chittilappilly | year=2010 | pages=250 | isbn=978-8130923987}} and Practical Wisdom 2: In Real Life and Management (2012).{{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.com/Practical-Wisdom-Real-Life-Management/dp/8130921197/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1439303527&sr=1-2 | title=Practical Wisdom 2: In Real Life and Management | publisher=Viva Books | author=Kochouseph Chittilappilly | year=2012 | pages=144 | isbn= 978-8130921198}} In between, he published his autobiographical work, ''Ormakkilivathil'' (Down Memory Lane) in 2011{{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.com/Ormakkilivathil-Kochouseph-Chittilappilly/dp/B007E5GXFU/ref=sr_1_4?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1439303527&sr=1-4 | title=Ormakkilivathil | publisher=DC Books | author=Kochouseph Chittilappilly | year=2011 | isbn=978-8126431243}} which had forewrod written by renowned Malayalam writer, [[T. Padmanabhan]].{{cite web | url=http://www.indulekha.com/ormakilivathil-memoirs-kochouseph-chittilappilly | title=Indulekha Ormakkilivathil | publisher=Indulekha | date=2015 | accessdate=11 August 2015}} ===Bibliography=== * {{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.com/Practical-Wisdom-Kochouseph-Chittilappilly/dp/B007E4Y8NA | title=Practical Wisdom | publisher=DC Books | author=Kochouseph Chittilappilly | year=2005 | ASIN=B007E4Y8NA}} * {{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.com/Practical-Wisdom-Real-Life-Management/dp/813092398X/ref=sr_1_1?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1439303527&sr=1-1 | title=Practical Wisdom 1: In Real Life and Management | publisher=Viva Books | author=Kochouseph Chittilappilly | year=2010 | pages=250 | isbn=978-8130923987}} * {{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.com/Ormakkilivathil-Kochouseph-Chittilappilly/dp/B007E5GXFU/ref=sr_1_4?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1439303527&sr=1-4 | title=Ormakkilivathil | publisher=DC Books | author=Kochouseph Chittilappilly | year=2011 | isbn=978-8126431243}} * {{cite book | url=https://www.amazon.com/Practical-Wisdom-Real-Life-Management/dp/8130921197/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1439303527&sr=1-2 | title=Practical Wisdom 2: In Real Life and Management | publisher=Viva Books | author=Kochouseph Chittilappilly | year=2012 | pages=144 | isbn= 978-8130921198}} * {{cite book | url=https://secure.mathrubhumi.com/books/biography/bookdetails/2839/ormakalilekku-oru-yathra | title= Ormakalilekku Oru Yathra | publisher=Mathrubhumi Books | author=Kochouseph Chittilappilly | year=2015 | pages=230 | isbn = 9788182665194 }} ==Philanthropic and humanitarian activities== [[File:ORGAN DONATION APPRECIATION FUNCTION.jpg|thumb]] K. Chittilapilly Foundation, founded by Kochouseph Chittilapilly, is a non profit organization and serves as the conduit for his philanthropic activities.{{cite web | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kochi/Chittilappilly-Foundation-declares-organ-donation-awards/articleshow/18455431.cms | title=Chittilappilly Foundation declares organ donation awards | publisher=Times of India | date=12 February 2013 | accessdate=12 August 2015}} The foundation, based in Kakkanadu, Kochi, also oversees the activities of Thomas Chittilapilly Trust, another charitable venture of Chittilapilly which is named after his father and runs two institutions, an old age home where elderly people are housed and provided with sustenance and medical care, and ''Shantimandiram'', a home for destitute children where they are provided with shelter, education and food. The institutions are managed by the Sisters of Nirmala Province, a provincialate of catholic nuns located at [[Kolazhy]] in [[Thrissur]]. It has also instituted an organ donation award for recognising people who come forward for organ donation and to promote organ donation among people. The foundation offers awards for those who voluntarily donate their own organs or to families who donate the organs of their [[brain death|brain-dead]] relatives; the awards carry cash components ranging from {{INR}}100,000 to {{INR}}500,000, totaling {{INR}}3.7 million every year. In 2011, Chittilapilly donated one of his kidneys to a stranger, a truck driver, and started an organ donor chain - where one of the family members of the recipient had to donate an organ thereby forming a donor chain. As a part of the programme, Chittilapilly donated one of his kidneys to a truck driver, becoming the first depositor with the [[Kidney Federation of India]] (KFI) and is now closely associated with the movement. ==Stray Dog Free movement== {{Main|Free-ranging dog issue of Kerala}} Chittilappilly is the chairman of the Stray Dog Free movement, which advocates action against the risks allegedly posed by [[stray dog]]s in Kerala, including the amendment of legislation forbidding the killing of these dogs.{{cite web | title=Kerala's Leading Businessman Goes on Hunger Strike Against Street Dogs | website=NDTV.com | date=2015-10-26 | url=http://www.ndtv.com/kerala-news/keralas-leading-businessman-goes-on-hunger-strike-against-street-dogs-1236253 | accessdate=2016-03-05}} The movement has pointed to the danger of [[rabies]] and referred to stray dogs as a "menace". Chittilappilly has staged hunger strikes to protest this legislation, and what he claims is governmental failure to address this issue.{{cite web | title=A day’s strike to tackle stray menace | website=The Hindu | date=2015-10-20 | url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/Kochi/a-days-strike-to-tackle-stray-menace/article7782645.ece | accessdate=2016-03-05}}{{cite web | title=Chittilappilly to stage hunger strike in T'puram | website=The Times of India | date=2016-02-07 | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/thiruvananthapuram/Chittilappilly-to-stage-hunger-strike-in-Tpuram/articleshow/50886686.cms | accessdate=2016-03-05}} He has stated that the government's actions amount to valuing stray dogs over human lives and property.{{cite web | last=Basheer | first=KPM | title=A dogged drive against stray dogs | website=The Hindu Business Line | date=2015-10-20 | url=http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/news/national/a-dogged-drive-against-stray-dogs/article7784837.ece | accessdate=2016-03-05}} He has encouraged citizens to pressure the government to amend these laws, and to kill stray dogs themselves despite the accompanying 50-[[rupee]] fine.{{cite web| title=Chittilappilly Stages Fast Against Stray Dog Menace | website=The New Indian Express | date=2016-03-05 | url=http://www.newindianexpress.com/states/kerala/Chittilappilly-Stages-Fast-Against-Stray-Dog-Menace/2016/02/21/article3288358.ece | accessdate=2016-03-05}}{{cite web | title=Chittilappilly launches hunger strike over stray dog menace | website=Mathrubhumi | date=2016-02-21 | url=http://english.mathrubhumi.com/news/kerala/chittilappilly-launches-hunger-strike-over-stray-dog-menace-english-news-1.879873 | accessdate=2016-03-05}} Chittilappilly has been arrested under statutes preventing cruelty to animals after tying four stray dogs in front of a police station.{{cite web | title=Chittilappilly booked for cruelty against strays | website=The Times of India | date=2015-10-20 | url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/kochi/Chittilappilly-booked-for-cruelty-against-strays/articleshow/49462105.cms | accessdate=2016-03-05}} The movement is related to governmental plans to cull stray dogs which have prompted an international campaign to "Boycott Kerala Tourism".{{cite web | last=Mohan | first=Neethu | title=Stray dogs culling: Boycott Kerala campaign gains momentum | website=www.oneindia.com | date=2015-07-14 | url=http://www.oneindia.com/india/stray-dogs-culling-boycott-kerala-campaign-gains-momentum-1806273.html | accessdate=2016-03-05}}{{cite web| title=How far will India's dog-lovers go to save strays? | website=BBC News | date=2015-08-10 | url=https://www.bbc.com/news/blogs-trending-33822511 | accessdate=2016-03-05}} Opponents of the Stray Dog Free movement have argued that [[Rabies vaccine#Other animals|vaccination]] and [[spay/neuter]] campaigns are a more effective and humane method of controlling the stray dog population. Members of the Stray Dog Free movement have alleged that opposition is being funded by [[rabies vaccine]] manufacturers.{{cite news |work=Prokerala | last=Ajeesh | first=A. | title=NGOs opposing culling of stray dogs financed by anti-rabies vaccine lobby: Collector Biju Prabhakar |date=2016-02-20}} == Awards == Chittilapilly is a recipient of ''Rashtriya Samman'' from the [[Government of India]] for being the highest tax payer in India. He was selected as the ''[[Malayala Manorama]] [[Newsmaker of the Year (Manorama News)|Newsmaker of the Year]] 2011'', the year he became an organ donor, the award reaching him in 2012. He is also a recipient of awards such as ''Millennium Businessman of Kerala'' from Business [[Deepika]], ''Tourism Man of the Year 2000'' from Destination Kerala, ''Manager of the Year 2000'' from the Travancore Management Association and ''Tourism Man of the Year 2011'' from the Association of Tourism Trade Organisations, India (ATTOI). ==See also== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Davis Chiramel]] * [[Kidney Federation of India]] * [[V-Guard Industries Ltd|V-Guard Industries]] * [[Wonderla]] * [[Free-ranging dog issue of Kerala]] {{div col end}} {{portal|India}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Kochouseph Chittilappilly}} *[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RQ9TvTkuOcE Promotional documentary about Chittilappily on YouTube] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chittilappilly, Kochouseph}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:St. Thomas College, Thrissur alumni]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Thrissur]] [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Malayali people]] [[Category:Indian industrialists]] [[Category:Indian philanthropists]] [[Category:Indian humanitarians]] [[Category:Cruelty to animals]]

{{multiple issues| {{notability|Events|date=December 2013}} {{third-party|date=December 2013}} }}
{{infobox music festival | | music_festival_name = Lakefest | image = | location = Croft Farm Waterpark, nr Tewkesbury, England until 2015 moved to Eastnor Castle deer park from 2016. | founder = [[Martin Newell]], [[Lee Martin]], [[Steve Daff]] | years_active = 2011-2018 | dates = Started 18th–19th May 2012 | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[World music|World]], [[Dance music|Dance]], [[Folk music|Folk]], | website = [http://www.lakefest.co.uk lakefest.co.uk] }}
'''Lakefest''' is a fairly new festival, which began as a music and cider festival, yet in its second year has booked big UK bands propelling it to the status of a full blown music festival.
== Origins ==
Lakesfest grew out from when Croft Farm Waterpark hosted its music and cider festival on 9th April 2011<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lakefest.co.uk/about/history |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-01-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126063513/http://lakefest.co.uk/about/history |archivedate=2012-01-26 |df= }}</ref> It was attended by just over 1,500 people consuming 8,500 pints of cider. Bands including The Stages of Dan, The Roving Crows and [[Wurzels|The Wurzels]] starred. Classic West Country games like Welly Wanging and skittles were available to play with a prizes up for grabs. The feedback was so positive that planning went immediately into "Lakefest".
== 2012 Festival lineup == The 2012 festival included the following acts:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://lakefest.co.uk/line-up-2012 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120419221052/http://lakefest.co.uk/line-up-2012 |archivedate=2012-04-19 |df= }}</ref><ref>http://www.efestivals.co.uk/festivals/others2012/lakefest/</ref>
'''Friday 9th''' * [[EMF (band)|EMF]] * Erica * Kickback * Rainy and the Dust * [[3 Daft Monkeys]] * [[Toploader]] * [[Reef (band)|Reef]]
'''Saturday 10th''' * [[Levellers (band)|Levellers]] * [[Dodgy]] * [[Chesney Hawkes]] * [[Roving Crows]] * [[The Wonderstuff]] * The Swing Man * Joe Wheldon * Smoke Feathers * ThunderRoad * Over The Hill * Missing Andy * Riff Raff * Avert Francis * Little Dave * Shippers * Timothy Parkes
== 2013 Festival Lineup == The 2013 Lakefest festival occurred over 3 days, on the weekend of 9th–11th August 2013. The 2013 festival included the following acts:<ref>http://lakefest.co.uk/2013-line-up/</ref>
'''Friday 9th''' *[[Ocean Colour Scene]] *[[The Beat (British band)|The Beat]] *Missing Andy *Chip Shop Boys *Ruffanti
'''Saturday 10th''' *[[Levellers (band)|Levellers]] *[[Roving Crows]] *[[The Crazy World Of Arthur Brown]] *[[Duke Special]] *[[Cosmo Jarvis]] *[[Baka Beyond]] *Erica *Gaz Brookfield *Funmilayo
'''Sunday 11th''' *[[Chas & Dave]] *[[3 Daft Monkeys]] *[[Jim Lockey & The Solemn Sun]] *Wille & The Bandits *Avert Francis
== 2014 Festival Lineup == The 2014 Lakefest festival occurred over 3 days, on the weekend of 8th–10th August 2014. The 2014 festival included the following acts:<ref>https://www.thefestivalcalendar.co.uk/festivals/Lakefest_2014</ref>
'''Friday 8th''' *[[Buzzcocks]] *[[Snap!]] *Bad Cardigan *Sons Of Navarone '''Saturday 9th''' *[[Shed Seven]] *[[The Lightning Seeds]] *[[the Bad Shepherds]] *Sarah Warren Band *Sons Of Earnest *[[ Neville Staple]] Band '''Sunday 10th''' *[[Fun Lovin' Criminals]] *The Roving Crows *Gaz Brookfield *[[Doctor and the Medics]]
== 2015 Festival Lineup == The 2015 Lakefest festival occurred over 3 days, on the weekend of 7–9th August 2015. The 2015 festival included the following acts:<ref>http://www.efestivals.co.uk/festivals/lakefest/2015/lineup.shtml</ref>
'''Friday 7th''' *[[Ash (band) |Ash]] *[[goldie lookin chain]] *babajack *haunted souls *lloyd yates *ferocious dog '''Saturday 8th''' *[[Billy Bragg]] *[[Embrace (English band)|Embrace]] *[[Cheeky Girls]] *Dreadzone *New Model Army Band *Notorious Brothers '''Sunday 9th''' *[[D Ream]] *[[Hayseed Dixie]] *[[Nizlopi]] *Simon Murphy *[[The Magic Numbers]] *The Roving Crows
== 2016 Festival Lineup == The 2016 Lakefest festival returned for a 5th year and moved to a new location at [[Eastnor Castle]] deer park nr Ledbury Herefordshire now occurred over 4 days,from 11–14th August 2016. The 2016 festival included the following acts:<ref>http://www.efestivals.co.uk/festivals/lakefest/2016</ref> Acts Appearing over the four days from Thursday -Sunday included to name a few:
*[[The Coral]] *[[Newton Faulkner]] *[[Starsailor (band) |Starsailor]] *[[Big Country]] *The Roving Crows * Jasper In The Company Of Others
== 2017 Festival Lineup == The 2017 Lakefest festival occurred over 4 days, from 10th–13th August 2017. The 2017 festival included the following acts:<ref>http://www.efestivals.co.uk/festivals/lakefest/2017/lineup.shtml</ref>
'''Thursday 10th''' *The No Good Nancys *Paul 0'Neil *Ash C *The Road *Zombies *Dead Frequency *Water for Dogs '''Friday 11th''' *[[Feeder (band)|Feeder]] *[[Wilko Johnson]] *Kila *The Minkie Whales '''Saturday 12th''' *[[The Charlatans (UK band)|The Charlatans]] *[[Alabama 3]] *[[Aswad (band)|Aswad]] *Arcadia Roots *[[Turin Brakes]] *Skewwhiff *Lost Boy '''Sunday 13th''' *[[Imelda May]] *[[Seth Lakeman]] *[[Badly Drawn Boy]] *The Roving Crows *Paul Terry *Josh Fletcher
== 2018 Festival Lineup == The 2018 Lakefest festival is due to occur over 4 days, from 9th–12th August 2018. The main acts have been revealed for the 2018 festival:<ref>http://www.efestivals.co.uk/festivals/lakefest/2018/</ref>
*[[Reverend And The Makers]] *[[Dub Pistols]] *[[Pop Will Eat Itself]] * Arcadia Roots *[[Marc Almond]] *[[Toploader]] *[[The Proclaimers]] *[[The Darkness (band)|The Darkness]] *[[The Farm (British band)|The Farm]] *[[Melanie C]] *[[Peter Hook and The Light]] *[[Roving Crows]]

{{verify|date=February 2018}} This is a '''list of current and defunct leagues of [[American football]] and [[Canadian football]]'''.
==Leagues in North America==
===Current leagues in North America===
'''Professional outdoor leagues''': *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[National Football League]], 1920– ::Originally American Professional Football Conference, American Professional Football Association (1920–1921) ::[[AFL–NFL merger|Merged]] with the [[American Football League]] (1960–69) *{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Canadian Football League]], 1909– ::Formed from [[Interprovincial Rugby Football Union]] (1907) and [[Western Interprovincial Football Union]] (1936). *{{Flagicon|MEX}} [[Liga de Fútbol Americano Profesional]], 2016– - '''Professional arena/indoor leagues''': *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Arena Football League]], (4 active teams and 1 on hiatus) 1987–2008, 2010– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Indoor Football League]], (10 teams) 2009– ::Formed from [[United Indoor Football]] and [[Intense Football League]] *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Champions Indoor Football]], (8 teams) 2015– ::Formed from [[Champions Professional Indoor Football League]] and [[Lone Star Football League]] *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[National Arena League]], (6 teams) 2017– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[American Arena League]], (6 teams) 2018– ::Formed from [[Arena Pro Football]] and [[Can-Am Indoor Football League]]
'''Semi-professional leagues''': *{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Northern Football Conference]], 1954– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Empire Football League]], 1969– *{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Alberta Football League]], 1984– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[New England Football League]], 1994– *{{Flagicon|USA}} Northeastern Football Alliance, 1997– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Rocky Mountain Football League]], 1997– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Central Football League (American football)|Central Football League]], 1999– *{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Maritime Football League]], 2002– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Minor League Football Association]], 2003– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Big Northeast Football Federation]] 2007– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Florida Football Alliance]], 2007– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Oklahoma Metro Football League]], 2007– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Regional American Football League]] 2007– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Five Star Football League]] 2010– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Gridiron Developmental Football League]] 2010– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Atlantic Football Association]], 2011– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Atlantic Coast Football Alliance]], 2009– <ref>http://www.acfafootball.net/</ref>– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Amateur to Professional Developmental Football League]], 2017– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[The Spring League]], 2017– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[East Coast Football Alliance]], 2011– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[A7FL|American 7s Football League]], 2014<ref>http://www.a7fl.com/about-a7fl/</ref>–
'''Collegiate and amateur leagues''': *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]], 1906– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[National Federation of State High School Associations]], 1920– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[California Community College Athletic Association]], 1929– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Sprint football|Collegiate Sprint Football League]], 1934– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[National Junior College Athletic Association]], 1938– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics]], 1940– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [http://www.intercollegiateclubfootball.com Intercollegiate Club Football Federation], 2010– *{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Canadian Junior Football League]], 1890– *{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[National Capital Amateur Football Association]], 1955– *{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[U Sports football|U Sports]], 1961– *{{Flagicon|MEX}} [[ONEFA|ONEFA: Organización Nacional Estudiantil de Fútbol Americano]], 1928– *{{Flagicon|MEX}} [[CONADEIP|CONADEIP: Comisión Nacional Deportiva Estudiantil de Instituciones Privadas]], 2010–
'''Women's leagues''': {{see also|Women's American football#Leagues}}
*{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Independent Women's Football League]], 2000– *{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Maritime Women's Football League]], 2004– *{{Flagicon|MEX}} Football Xtremo Femenil, 2006– *{{Flagicon|USA}}{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Legends Football League]], 2009– ::Originally known as the Lingerie Football League from 2009 to 2013. *{{Flagicon|USA}}{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Women's Football Alliance]], 2009– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[United States Women's Football League]], 2010– *{{Flagicon|MEX}} Asociación de Football Femenil Equipado, 2010– *{{Flagicon|CAN}} [[Western Women's Canadian Football League]], 2011– *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Women's Arena Football League]], 2012– *{{Flagicon|MEX}} Liga Mexicana de Football Lingerie, 2012– *{{Flagicon|MEX}} Pretty Girls Football League, 2012– *{{Flagicon|MEX}} Liga Iberoamericana de Bikini Football, 2012– *{{Flagicon|MEX}} Women's Football League, 2015–<ref>https://www.facebook.com/WFLoficial/about/</ref>
===Planned leagues in North America=== *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[XFL (2020)|XFL]], Begins in 2020 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Alliance of American Football]], Begins in 2019 *[[National Gridiron League (indoor)]], proposed to begin in 2019
===Historical leagues in North America===
'''Major outdoor leagues:''' *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Western Pennsylvania Professional Football Circuit]], 1892–1940<sup>6</sup> ::Known as the Western Pennsylvania Senior Independent Football Conference from 1920s onward. *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[National Football League (1902)]] and the [[World Series of Football (1902)|World Series of Pro Football]], 1902–1903 *{{Flagicon|USA}} Ohio Independent Championship ([[Ohio League]]), 1903–1919<sup>6</sup> *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[New York Pro Football League]], c. 1913–1920<sup>6</sup> *{{Flagicon|USA}} American Football League, [[American Football League (1926)|1926]], [[American Football League (1936)|1936–1937]], [[American Football League (1940)|1940–1941]], and [[American Football League|1960–1969]]<sup>2</sup> (all unrelated, four separate leagues) *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[All-America Football Conference]], 1946–1949<sup>1</sup> *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[World Football League]], 1974–1975 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[United States Football League]], 1983–1985 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[XFL]], 2001 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[United Football League (2009–12)|United Football League]], 2009–2012
'''Minor outdoor leagues''' *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Anthracite League]] (1924) / [[Eastern League of Professional Football]] (1926) *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[American Football League (1934)|American Football League]], 1934 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Midwest Football League (1935–1940)|Midwest Football League]], 1935–1937, became [[American Football League (1938)|American Professional Football Association]] in 1938, American Football League in 1939 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Dixie League (football)|Dixie League]], 1936–1947 – originally South Atlantic Football Association *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[American Association (football)|American Association]] 1936–1941/[[American Football League (1946)|American Football League]] 1946–1950<sup>3</sup> *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[American Football League (1938)|American Football League]], 1938–1939<sup>4</sup> *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Pacific Coast Professional Football League]], 1940–1948 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[American Football League (1944)|American Football League]], 1944<sup>5</sup> *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[United Football League (1961)|United Football League]], 1961–1964 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Atlantic Coast Football League]], 1962–1971, 1973 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Continental Football League]], 1965–1969 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[North American Football League (1965-66)|North American Football League]], 1965–1966 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Seaboard Football League]], 1971–1974 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[American Football Association (1978–1983)|American Football Association]], 1978–1983 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[International Football League]], 1984<ref>http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/vault/article/magazine/MAG1121180/index.htm</ref> *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Professional Spring Football League]], 1992 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Regional Football League]], 1999 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[International Football Federation]], 2000 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Spring Football League]], 2000 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Southern States Football League]], 2001–2009 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[United Football League (2009–12)|United Football League]], 2009–2012 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Stars Football League]], 2011–2013 *{{Flagicon|USA}} [[Fall Experimental Football League]], 2014–2015 *<sup>1</sup>: Two teams now in NFL *<sup>2</sup>: Agreed to merger with the NFL in 1966, with merger completed in 1970 *<sup>3</sup>: American Association suspended operations for duration of U.S. involvement in [[World War II]]; in 1946 the AA was renamed American Football League *<sup>4</sup>: Known as the American Professional Football Association in 1938; renamed American Football League in 1939; dissolution after 1939 season caused by formation of 1940–1941 AFL major league *<sup>5</sup>: Merged with PCPFL in 1945 *<sup>6</sup>: Informal association of teams
