page.title: List of assassinations by the Assassins
List of people assassinated by the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam

revision.text:
The following is a '''list of notable people assassinated by the [[Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]]''', commonly known as Tamil Tigers or as LTTE.<ref>{{cite news | first=Rohan | last=Gunaratna | title=Intelligence failures exposed by Tamil Tiger airport attack | date=2001-11-03 | url =http://www.janes.com/security/international_security/news/jir/jir010903_1_n.shtml | work =Jane's Information Group | accessdate = 2007-04-27 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070303021604/http://www.janes.com/security/international_security/news/jir/jir010903_1_n.shtml <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2007-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Audrey Kurth Cronin |author2=Huda Aden |author3=Adam Frost |author4=Benjamin Jones |last-author-amp=yes | title=CRS Report for Congress, Foreign Terrorist Organizations | date=2004-02-06 | publisher=The Library of Congress | url =https://fas.org/irp/crs/RL32223.pdf | work =Bureau of Consular Affairs | accessdate = 2015-04-29 |format=PDF}}</ref> The LTTE is a now-defunct militant organisation that was based in northern Sri Lanka, which [[Sri Lankan Civil War|fought]] for a separate [[Tamil Eelam|Tamil state]] in the [[Northern Province, Sri Lanka|north]] and [[Eastern Province, Sri Lanka|east]] of [[Sri Lanka]] between 1983 and 2009.<ref>[http://www.irinnews.org/report/84146/sri-lanka-conflict-timeline Sri Lanka Conflict timeline], IRIN Asia</ref> The LTTE was decisively defeated by the [[Sri Lankan Military]] in May 2009 and it has been banned by 30 countries, including the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[India]] and the 27 member nations of the [[European Union]].<ref>[http://www.worldwatch.org/node/4373 The European Union Lists Sri Lanka's Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) as a Banned Terrorist Organization], Worldwatch Institute</ref> At the height of its power, the LTTE possessed a well-developed militia and carried out many high-profile attacks, including the assassinations of an Indian prime minister, Sri Lankan president and several other high-ranking Sri Lankan politicians.<ref>[https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/2008/january/tamil_tigers011008 Taming the Tamil Tigers], The FBI</ref><ref name=x12/><ref name=y12/><ref name=JI/> Some of the notable people who survived the assassination attempts of LTTE, are also included at the bottom of this list.
==Heads of state and government== * [[Ranasinghe Premadasa]]<ref name=y12>{{Cite news|title=Sri Lanka assassination plot |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/south_asia/140084.stm |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=27 July 1998 |accessdate=2014-03-03}}</ref><ref name=Hindu050905>{{Cite news|first=V. S. |last=Sambandan |title=Inquiries into Premadasa, Dissanayake killings closed |url=http://www.hindu.com/2005/09/05/stories/2005090507041200.htm |publisher=[[The Hindu]] |date=5 September 2005 |accessdate=2014-03-03 |location=Chennai, India}}</ref> - Former [[President of Sri Lanka]] * [[Rajiv Gandhi]]<ref name=x12>{{Cite news|title=Tamil Tiger 'regret' over Gandhi |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/5122032.stm |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=27 June 2006 |accessdate=2014-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=On This Day 21 May - 1991: Bomb kills India's former leader Rajiv Gandhi |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/21/newsid_2504000/2504739.stm |publisher=[[BBC]] |accessdate=2014-03-03 | date=21 May 1991}}</ref> - Former [[Prime Minister of India]]
==Government ministers== * [[Lalith Athulathmudali]]<ref name="Jane">{{cite web |url=http://tamilnation.co/ltte/00jane.htm | title=Jane's Sentinel on LTTE success in resisting Sri Lankan forces | publisher=Tamil Nation | date=4 September 2000 | accessdate=11 April 2014}}</ref>{{Efn|Other sources blame Athulathmudali's assassination on the [[Sri Lankan Security Forces|Security Forces]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Rajasingham|first=K. T.|title=Sri Lanka: The Untold Story|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/DI21Df01.html|chapter=Chapter 58: Premadasa indicted}}</ref>}} - Former Sri Lankan Cabinet Minister of Trade, National Security, Agriculture, Education and deputy minister of defence. * [[Gamini Dissanayake]]<ref name=JI>[http://tamilnation.co/ltte/00jane.htm Jane's Sentinel on LTTE success in resisting Sri Lankan forces], Tamil nation</ref><ref name="satp" /> - Former [[United National Party]] presidential candidate and Leader of the Opposition, Former Sri Lankan Cabinet Minister of Irrigation, Power, Highways, Land, Land Development, Plantation Industries, Mahaweli and Mahaweli Development & Former chairman of the [[Sri Lanka Cricket Board]] * [[Ranjan Wijeratne]]<ref name=JI/><ref>{{Cite news|title=On This Day 2 March - 1991: Sri Lankan hardliner among 19 killed in blast|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/march/2/newsid_4201000/4201675.stm|publisher=[[BBC]] |date=2 March 1991|accessdate=2014-03-03}}</ref> - Former Sri Lankan Cabinet Minister of Foreign Affairs, Plantation Industries and Minister of State for Defense * [[Lakshman Kadirgamar]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2006/08/17/stories/2006081706820800.htm |title=The LTTE's war trap, The Hindu |publisher=Hindu.com |date=2006-08-17 |accessdate=2014-03-03}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/4147196.stm |title=Senior Sri Lanka minister killed |accessdate=2014-03-03|work=BBC News | date=August 13, 2005 | location=London}}</ref> Former Sri Lankan Cabinet Minister of Foreign Affairs of Sri Lanka, Prominent Tamil diplomat, politician and lawyer. * [[Jeyaraj Fernandopulle]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/sinhala/news/story/2008/04/080409_amnesty_tmvp.shtml|title=BBCSinhala.com|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref> - Former Sri Lankan Cabinet Minister of Highways & Road Development, the chief government whip of the parliament of Sri Lanka * [[C. V. Gunaratne]]<ref name=JI/><ref name="satp" /> - Former Sri Lankan Cabinet Minister of Industries Development. * [[Weerasinghe Mallimarachchi]]<ref name=JI/><ref name="satp" /> - Former Sri Lankan Cabinet Minister of Food, Co-operative, and Janasaviya-Poverty Alleviation * [[G. M. Premachandra]]<ref name=JI/><ref name="satp" /> - Former Sri Lankan Cabinet Minister of Labour and Vocational Training * [[D. M. Dassanayake]]<ref>{{Cite news|title=D.M. Dassanayake, a Sri Lankan minister, is killed by bomb|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/08/world/asia/08iht-lanka.1.9075692.html|publisher=[[New York Times]] |date=8 January 2008 |accessdate=2014-03-03}}</ref> - Former Sri Lankan non-cabinet Minister of Nation Building
==Members of Sri Lankan parliament== * [[Ossie Abeygunasekera]]<ref name=JI/><ref name="satp">{{cite web |url=http://www.satp.org/satporgtp/countries/shrilanka/database/leaders_assassinated_byLTTE.htm | title=Prominent Political Leaders Assassinated by The LTTE | publisher=South Asia Terrorism Portal | accessdate=11 April 2014}}</ref> - Former Chairman and Leader of the [[Sri Lanka Mahajana Pakshaya]], Former candidate of the Presidential election in 1989 * [[A. Amirthalingam]]<ref name =as>{{cite news|last=[[D. B. S. Jeyaraj]]|title=Assassinating Tamil Parliamentarians: The unceasing waves|url=http://www.nation.lk/2008/03/16/newsfe1.htm|newspaper=The Nation, Sri Lanka|date=16 March 2008}}</ref><ref name=ad>{{cite book|last=Rajasingham|first=K. T.|title=SRI LANKA: THE UNTOLD STORY|url=http://www.atimes.com/ind-pak/DE11Df02.html|chapter=Chapter 39: Amirthalingham eliminated}}</ref> - Leading [[Sri Lankan Tamil]] politician and former [[Leader of the Opposition (Sri Lanka)|Leader of the Opposition]]. * [[A. Thangathurai]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amnesty.org/en/documents/asa37/020/1997/en/|title=Document - Sri Lanka: Tamil Tigers leaders should account for latest killings - Amnesty International|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref>- Former [[Tamil United Liberation Front]] (TULF) Member of Parliament for [[Trincomalee District]]. * [[Alfred Duraiappah]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uthr.org/Book/CHA02.htm#_Toc527947383|title=Welcome to UTHR, Sri Lanka|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref> - Former [[Sri Lanka Freedom Party]] member of the parliament for Jaffna District and former mayor of [[Jaffna]]. * [[M. Canagaratnam]]<ref name="CAN">{{cite web |url=http://www.atimes.com/ind-pak/DB02Df03.html | title=SRI LANKA: THE UNTOLD STORY - Chapter 27 - Horsewhip Amirthalingham | publisher=Asia Times | date=February 2, 2002 | accessdate=11 April 2014 | author=Rajasingham , KT}}</ref> Former [[Tamil United Liberation Front]] MP for Pottuvil * [[A. L. Abdul Majeed]]<ref>[http://www.asiantribune.com/news/2005/12/26/ltte-has-so-far-killed-25-parliamentarians LTTE has so far killed 25 parliamentarians]</ref> - Former Sri Lanka Freedom Party MP for Mutur * [[S. Shanmuganathan (Sri Lankan politician)|S. Shanmuganathan]]<ref name =as/> Former [[Democratic People's Liberation Front]] MP for [[Vanni District]] * [[Nimalan Soundaranayagam]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Special Report No 17 - Rewarding Tyranny: Undermining the Democratic Potential for Peace|url=http://www.uthr.org/SpecialReports/spreport17.htm|publisher=[[University Teachers for Human Rights]]|date=7 October 2003}}</ref> - Former [[Tamil United Liberation Front]] MP for [[Batticaloa District]] * [[Sam Tambimuttu]]<ref name="satp" /><ref>[http://www.island.lk/index.php?page_cat=article-details&page=article-details&code_title=35478 Batti political family scion beckons Tamils away from politics of hate], The Island</ref> Former [[Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front]] MP for Batticaloa District * [[Neelan Tiruchelvam]]<ref>[http://www.indianexpress.com/res/web/pIe/ie/daily/19990730/ige30066.html Suicide bomber kills Lankan MP]</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/406644.stm | work=BBC News | title=Sri Lanka: Tamil politician assassinated | date=July 29, 1999 | accessdate=2014-03-03}}</ref> - Scholar, international activist, legislator, lawyer, social scientist and politician. Former Member of the Sri Lanka Parliament from National List * [[G. Yogasangari]]<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Subramanian |first=T. S. |title=Chronicle of murders |magazine=[[Frontline (magazine)|Frontline]] |date=14 August 1999 |volume=16 |issue=17 |url=http://www.hindu.com/fline/fl1617/16171020.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110123525/http://www.hindu.com/fline/fl1617/16171020.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=10 November 2012 |issn=0970-1710 }}</ref> - Former Eelam People's Revolutionary Liberation Front MP for Jaffna District * [[V. Yogeswaran]]<ref name =as /><ref name=ad /> Former Tamil United Liberation Front MP for Jaffna district
==Senior military and police officers== * Admiral [[Clancy Fernando]]<ref name="Jane" /> - Former Commander of the [[Sri Lanka Navy]] * Lieutenant General [[Denzil Kobbekaduwa]]<ref name="Jane" />{{Efn|name=Rajasingham|Other sources blame Jayamaha, Kobbekaduwa and Wimalaratne's assassinations on the [[Sri Lankan Army|Army]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Rajasingham|first=K. T.|title=Sri Lanka: The Untold Story|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/DH10Df01.html|chapter=Chapter 52: President blamed for assassinations}}</ref>}} - General Officer Commanding, Northern Sector, [[Sri Lankan Army]] * Lieutenant General [[Parami Kulatunga]]<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/5115968.stm Sri Lanka general killed in blast] - BBC News</ref> - Deputy Chief of Staff, [[Sri Lankan Army]] * Lieutenant Generall [[Nalin Angammana]]<ref name="cnn">{{cite web | url=http://www-cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/0112/feat2.html | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120805212347/http://www-cgi.cnn.com/ASIANOW/asiaweek/96/0112/feat2.html | dead-url=yes | archive-date=5 August 2012 | title=Passage - Died | publisher=Asiaweek | accessdate=11 April 2014 }}</ref> - General Officer Commanding, 3rd Army Division, Sri Lankan Army * Major General [[Lucky Wijayaratne]]<ref name="Jane" /> - Former Commander, 22 Brigade, Sri Lanka Army * Major General [[Larry Wijeratne]]<ref>[http://www.infolanka.com/org/srilanka/issues/ut18.html Brigadier Larry Wijeratne's Legacy]- UTHR(Jaffna)-Sri Lanka</ref> -Former Brigade Commander, 51-4 Brigade * Major General [[Lakshman Algama]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.island.lk/index.php?page_cat=article-details&page=article-details&code_title=64041|title=The Island|publisher=|accessdate=17 December 2014}}</ref> - Former Chief of Staff of the Sri Lanka Army * Major General [[Vijaya Wimalaratne]]<ref name="Jane" />{{Efn|name=Rajasingham}} - Former Commander of Jaffna, Sri Lanka Army * Major General [[Percy Fernando]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sundaytimes.lk/010422/spec.html | title=The fall of Elephant Pass | publisher=The Sunday Times | accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> - Former Deputy General Officer Commanding, 54 Division, Sri Lanka Army * Major General [[Ananda Hamangoda]]<ref name="cnq">[http://www.sundaytimes.lk/960707/sitrep.html Situation Report 7th July 1996 - How 2 brave soldiers saved minister By Iqbal Athas] www.sundaytimes.lk</ref> - Former Brigade Commander, 51-2 Brigade, Sri Lanka Army * Major General Susantha Mendis<ref name="ss"/> - Former Brigade Commander, 51-4 Brigade * Major General [[Janaka Perera]]<ref name="JP">{{cite web |url=http://www.asiantribune.com/node/13551 | title=Maj Gen Janaka Perera and his wife killed in LTTE suicide attack in Anuradhapura | publisher=Asian Tribune | accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> - Former Chief of Staff of the Sri Lanka Army, Former High Commissioner to Australia & Ambassador to Indonesia, Former opposition leader of the [[North Central Provincial Council]] * Rear Admiral Mohan Jayamaha<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.news.lk/news/item/2232-lt-gen-denzil-kobbekaduwa-other-heroes-remembered-at-araly | title=Lt Gen Denzil Kobbekaduwa & Other Heroes Remembered at Araly | publisher=News.lk | accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref>{{Efn|name=Rajasingham}} - Former Commander, Northern Naval Area, Sri Lanka Navy * Air Commodore [[Shirantha Goonatilake]]<ref name="shir">{{cite web |url=http://archives.dailynews.lk/2006/11/25/spice01.asp | title=Harry Goonatilake, a true patriot | publisher=Daily News- Spice | accessdate=1 September 2014}}</ref> - Former Commanding Officer of [[No. 1 Wing SLAF|No. 1 Flying Training Wing]], [[Sri Lanka Air Force]] * Colonel [[Tuan Nizam Muthaliff]]<ref>[http://www.nation.lk/2009/05/31/news16.htm Fourth anniversary of Col. [[File:Lone Pine cemetery May 2002.jpg|250px|thumb|Lone Pine at [[Lone Pine Cemetery]], Gallipoli - ''Pinus pinea'']] The '''Lone Pine''' was a solitary tree on the [[Gallipoli Peninsula]] in [[Turkey]], which marked the site of the [[Battle of Lone Pine]] in 1915. It was a "Turkish Pine" of species ''[[Pinus brutia]]''. [[Pinus|Pines]] which are planted as a memorial to the [[Australian and New Zealand Army Corps|Australian and New Zealand soldiers]] who fought in Gallipoli are also known as "Lone Pines" or "Gallipoli Pines". However, there are at least two species of pine in that locality—in addition to "Turkish Pine" ''Pinus brutia'', the "Aleppo Pine" ''Pinus halepensis'' is also common. Branches from "Allepo" pines were also used by the Turks to protect their trenches, and cones and seeds from "Allepo" pines are common at "Lone Pine" memorials in Australia, in particular, the tree at the [[Australian War Memorial]]. The tree at the [[Lone Pine Cemetery]] at Gallipoli is of a third species—[[Stone pine]] ''Pinus pinea''. ==The original "Lone Pine"== The "original" Lone Pine, a "Turkish Pine" of species ''Pinus brutia'', was the sole survivor of a group of trees that had been cut down by Turkish soldiers who had used the timber and branches to cover their trenches during the battle. They has also cut down other trees to do this, most particularly "Aleppo Pines" ''Pinus halepensis''. The tree was obliterated during the battle; however, pine cones that had remained attached to the cut branches over the trenches were retrieved by various Australian soldiers and brought home to Australia. The resultant seedlings sent home by one soldier were found to be [[Turkish pine]]s, but those sent home by a pair of soldiers were found to be ''Pinus halepensis'' ([[Aleppo pine]]). Initially, Turkish pines were regarded as a subspecies of ''Pinus halepensis'' ([[Aleppo pine]]), but now they are usually classified as a distinct species, ''[[Pinus brutia]]''.Spencer, R.D. (1995) ''Horticultural Flora of South-eastern Australia'' 1: 248-249 (University of NSW Press). ==Tree at Lone Pine Cemetery, Gallipoli== At the [[Lone Pine Commonwealth War Graves Commission Cemetery|Lone Pine Cemetery]] on the Gallipoli peninsula, a solitary pine was planted in the 1920s to symbolise the original Lone Pine. This tree was inspected in 1987 by an Australian botanist and confirmed to be a [[stone pine]] (''Pinus pinea'').{{cite web |title= Champion Trees in Commonwealth War Cemeteries |publisher=Commonwealth War Graves Commission |url=http://www.cwgc.org/admin/files/CHAMPIONTREES.pdf |accessdate=29 March 2012 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721100247/http://www.cwgc.org/admin/files/CHAMPIONTREES.pdf |archivedate=21 July 2011 }} {{coord|40|13|49.48|N|26|17|14.74|E|region:TR_type:landmark|display=title}} ==Trees in Australia== [[File:Lone Pine Wattle Park.jpg|thumb|Lone Pine at [[Wattle Park, Melbourne|Wattle Park]] (Melbourne) - ''Pinus brutia'']] [[File:Lone Pine at the AWM.jpg|thumb|Lone Pine at the Australian War Memorial (Canberra) -
''Pinus halepensis'']] Keith McDowell, an Australian soldier of the [[23rd Battalion (Australia)|23rd Battalion]] who fought at Gallipoli, brought a pine cone from the battle site home to Australia.{{cite book | url = http://www.shrine.org.au/getattachment/c074a957-26b4-44b8-9358-a7bb18a93150/The-Shrine--Background.aspx |format=PDF| chapter = The Shrine Reserve | title = Shrine of Remembrance Education Program: Background Information | publisher = Shrine of Remembrance | accessdate = 29 March 2012| pages = 8–10}} Many years later seeds from the cone were planted by his wife's aunt Emma Gray of Grassmere, near [[Warrnambool|Warrnambool, Victoria]] and five seedlings emerged, with four surviving. These seedlings were planted in four different locations in Victoria: [[Wattle Park, Melbourne]] (8 May 1933), the [[Shrine of Remembrance]] (11 June 1933), the Soldiers Memorial Hall at [[The Sisters, Victoria|The Sisters]] near Terang (18 June 1933) and [[Warrnambool]] Botanic Gardens (23 January 1934).{{cite web |title=Gallipoli "Lone Pine" lives on |publisher=Legacy |url=http://www.balmoralcemetery.com/00_pdfs/gallipoli_lone_pine.pdf |accessdate=29 March 2012}} The tree at the Shrine Reserve was planted near the north-east corner of the building by [[Stanley Savige|Lieutenant-General Sir Stanley Savige]], founder of Melbourne Legacy, at a formal ceremony.{{cite web |title=Lone Pine – Shrine Reserve |publisher=City of Melbourne |url=http://www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/info.cfm?top=26&pg=1749 |accessdate=29 March 2012 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060916220445/http://www.melbourne.vic.gov.au/info.cfm?top=26&pg=1749 |archivedate=16 September 2006 }} In 2005 the tree required cable bracing following the loss of a major limb and in August 2012, despite measures taken to try to save the tree from the effects of disease caused by the fungus ''[[Diplodia pinea]]'', it was removed.{{cite news |last=Smethurst |first=Annika |author-link=Annika Smethurst |title= Melbourne's Lone Pine tree, planted with seeds from Gallipoli Peninsula, has been cut down |date=24 August 2012 |url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/victoria/melbournes-lone-pine-tree-planted-with-seeds-from-gallipoli-peninsula-has-been-cut-down/story-e6frf7kx-1226457038292 |accessdate=28 September 2012 |newspaper=[[Herald Sun]] |publisher=News Corp Australia}} A "grandchild tree" was planted nearby in 2006.{{cite news |author=Smith, Bridie |title=Shrine's Lone Pine facing battle to death with attacking fungus |work = The Age |date=22 June 2012 |url= http://www.theage.com.au/victoria/shrines-lone-pine-facing-battle-to-death-with-attacking-fungus-20120621-20qzt.html |accessdate=1 July 2012}} A [[Middle Park, Victoria|Middle Park]] man, Andrew Lees, collected cones from the broken limb in 2005 and by 2015 had managed to germinate about 20 seedlings.{{cite news |url=http://www.theweeklyreviewbayside.com.au/story/1831805/anzac-day-no-need-to-pine-for-a-chip-off-the-old-block/ |title=No need to pine for a chip off the old block |publisher=The Weekly Review Bayside |date=9 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402120022/http://www.theweeklyreviewbayside.com.au/story/1831805/anzac-day-no-need-to-pine-for-a-chip-off-the-old-block/ |archivedate=2 April 2015 |df= }} Another soldier, Lance Corporal Benjamin Smith from the [[3rd Battalion (Australia)|3rd Battalion]], also retrieved a cone from the battle site and sent it back to his mother in Australia, (Mrs McMullen), who had lost another son at the battle. Seeds from the cone were planted by her in 1928, from which two seedlings were raised. One was presented to her home town of [[Inverell, New South Wales]] and the other was forwarded to [[Canberra]] where it was planted by [[Prince Henry, Duke of Gloucester]] at the [[Australian War Memorial]] (AWM) in October 1934.{{cite web |title=The Lone Pine Tree |publisher=Australian War Memorial |url=https://www.awm.gov.au/encyclopedia/lone.asp|accessdate=29 March 2012}} The AWM lone pine lost two of its large lower limbs by strong winds preceding a thunderstorm on 27 December 2008. However, tree surgeons were able to save the historic tree.{{cite news|last=Dodd |first=Mark |title=Living war memorial at risk |work=News Limited |publisher=[[The Australian]] |date=2008-12-29 |url=http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0,25197,24850359-31477,00.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081231155352/http://www.theaustralian.news.com.au/story/0%2C25197%2C24850359-31477%2C00.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2008-12-31 |accessdate=2009-01-11 |df= }}{{cite news | last = Lane | first = Sabra | title = Australian War Memorial's Lone Pine will survive | work = Australian Broadcasting Corporation | publisher = AM | date = 2008-12-30 | url = http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2008/s2456478.htm | accessdate = 2009-01-11}} Both Melbourne Legacy and the Yarralumla Nursery in Canberra have raised and grown seedlings over a number of years, sourced from the tree at the Shrine of Remembrance and the Australian War Memorial respectively, which they have presented to schools as well as ex-service and other organisations throughout Australia.{{cite journal |author1=Wilcox, Mike |author2=Spencer David |title=Stand up for the real Anzac Lone Pine of Gallipoli |journal=New Zealand Journal of Forestry |volume=52 |number=1 |year= 2007 |pages=3–9 |url=http://nzjf.org.nz/free_issues/NZJF52_1_2007/ABC34FDA-39BA-438B-B1B1-7A236CAE712B.pdf |accessdate=11 February 2017}} Other "Lone Pines" include: *Plaques at the base of the pine tree at the Oatley Park Avenue entrance to [[Oatley Park, New South Wales|Oatley Park]], NSW, state it was planted in 1920 by Owen Jones Davies from pine cones obtained from Lone Pine, Gallipoli. *The two Lone Pine seedlings at the [[Australian Defence Force Academy]] in [[Canberra]] were presented by the [[Returned and Services League of Australia|RSL]] on [[Remembrance Day]], 11 November 1987. *The pine at the Battle of Lone Pine memorial at Adelaide's [[National War Memorial (South Australia)#Adjacent memorials|National War Memorial]] is accompanied by a plaque stating "This pine is a seedling related to the original Lone Pine on Gallipoli" *A seedling of ''[[Pinus brutia]]'', propagated from the original tree at Lone Pine was planted in the grounds of the [[Victorian School of Forestry]] at [[Creswick, Victoria|Creswick]] on 23 March 1975.{{Cite web|url=https://omeka.cloud.unimelb.edu.au/cchc/items/show/6808|title=Pinus brutia (lone pine). ,” Creswick Campus Historical Collection|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} A plaque was also unveiled by [[Legacy Australia|Legacy]]. ''Pinus halepensis'' File:Manangatang Lone Pine Plaque.JPG ==Trees in New Zealand== In [[Auckland]], two trees identified as "Lone Pines" have been planted. One is a ''[[Pinus canariensis]]'' planted at [[Waikumete Cemetery|Waikumete cemetery]] in 1961 and another is a ''[[Pinus radiata]]'' at [[Auckland War Memorial Museum]], planted on [[Anzac Day]] in 1950. A tree identified as "The Anzac Pine" stands on [[Te Mata Peak]] at Havelock North in Hawkes Bay. Although a specimen of ''Pinus brutia'' was originally planted, the current tree is identified as the species ''Pinus radiata''. Two specimens of ''[[Pinus halepensis]]'', planted in 1951, are located at the Lone Pine Memorial at the cemetery in [[Taradale, New Zealand|Taradale]], and further specimens are located at King Edward Park in [[Stratford, New Zealand|Stratford]] and Queens Park in [[Wanganui]]. There is a "Lone Pine" at the Paeroa golf course, at the ladies tee, on the second hole. This tree appears to be New Zealand's only authentic ''Pinus brutia'' that can be traced back to the original pines, according to "Excerpts from NZ Journal of Forestry, May 2007". Also, in [[Victoria Park, Christchurch]], there is a plaque which claims that the nearby pine tree was grown from a seedling of the Gallipoli Lone Pine. ==References== {{Reflist|20em}} {{Commons category|Lone Pine (tree)}} [[Category:2010s individual tree deaths]] [[Category:Gallipoli Campaign]] [[Category:Individual conifers]] [[Category:Individual trees in Turkey]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in Australia]] [[Category:Monuments and memorials in New Zealand]]

[[File:Measuring the Universe by Roman Ondak.jpg|thumb|On view in Pinakothek der Moderne, Munich (2007).]] {{italic title}} '''''Measuring the Universe''''' is a [[performance art]] work by [[Slovaks|Slovak]] artist [[Roman Ondak]] first installed in the [[Pinakothek der Moderne]] in [[Munich]] in 2007.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Measuring the Universe|last = Ondák|first = Roman|publisher = JRP{{!}}Ringier|year = 2009|isbn = 978-3-03764-024-1|location = Unknown|pages = 1}}</ref> The exhibition stars as a blank white wall and begins to fill when museum guards mark visitors' height along with their name and the current date. It is in the collection of [[Tate Modern]] in [[London]], [[Pinakothek der Moderne|Pinakother der Moderne]] in [[Munich]] and [[Museum of Modern Art|MoMa]] in [[New York City|New York]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.tate.org.uk/context-comment/video/tateshots-roman-ondak-measuring-universe|title = TateShots: Roman Ondak, Measuring the Universe|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
==Materials== The only items required for the installation were a white room and a few black markers. What began as a clean white space has been filled with letters and lines and numbers as people pass through the gallery. Each tiny line represents a different person. The thousands and thousands of lines show just how many people pass through the museum each day, how many people were, affected by this installation.

{{Multiple issues| {{One source|date=December 2014}} {{Notability|date=December 2014}} }} The 1969 '''murder of Diane Maxwell''' involved the death of Diane Maxwell, a 25-year-old phone operator for [[Southwestern Bell]], who was found raped and killed in a shack in December 1969 in [[Houston, Texas]].
==Crime== On December 14, 1969, 25-year-old Diane Maxwell (b. 1944) was walking to her job as a phone operator for Southwestern Bell, but never made it to the building. Later that day, a man by the name of William Bell noticed a man walking away from a shack. When Bell came to look in the shack, he found the raped, dead body of Maxwell, and immediately notified police.
However, the case remained unsolved due to the lack of computer technology. In 1986, seventeen years after the incident, they reopened the case, but could not solve it again, and the case remained closed until July 2003, 34 years after the murder was committed. A batch of forensics they had performed in 1969 was found by Houston police, who located James Ray Davis, a lifetime criminal, last convicted of kidnapping a young girl, who was considered the perpetrator of the Maxwell rape and murder, which was confirmed by DNA evidence, which established that he did rape her. Davis was convicted of first degree murder (the robbery, rape, and kidnapping statute of limitations had expired) shortly afterward, and was sentenced to life without parole.
In 2008, the case was featured in the ''[[Forensic Files]]'' episode "Brotherly Love."
==Sources== *[https://www.fbi.gov/news/stories/2011/october/print_101411/ FBI report on the murder Diane Maxwell], Houston Cold Case Solved; accessed 19 December 2014

revision.text:
{{Infobox newspaper | name =Novy Chas | logo = | image = | caption = | type = [[Weekly newspaper]] | format = | owners = | founder = | publisher = [[Frantsishak Skaryna Belarusian Language Society]] | editor = | chiefeditor = | assoceditor = | maneditor = | newseditor = | managingeditordesign = | campuseditor = | campuschief = | opeditor = | sportseditor = | photoeditor = | staff = | foundation = March {{start date and age|2007}} | political = Independent
[[Liberalism|liberal]] | language = [[Belarussian language|Belarusian]] | ceased publication = | headquarters = [[Minsk]] | circulation = | sister newspapers = ''[[Nasha Slova]]'' | ISSN = | oclc = | website = }} '''''Novy Chas''''' (''New Time'' in English){{cite journal|author=Dimiter Kenarov|title=Tongue Oppressor|journal=Columbia Journalism Review|date=2 March 2012|url=http://www.cjr.org/feature/tongue_oppressor.php?page=all&print=true|accessdate=23 January 2014}} is an independent weekly newspaper published in [[Belarus]]. ==History and profile== ''Novy Chas'' was established on 1 March 2007 as a successor to ''[[Zgoda (newspaper)|Zgoda]]'' which was shut down in 2007.{{cite news|title=Independent Belarusian Newspaper Threatened With Closure|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1079242.html|accessdate=23 January 2014|newspaper=Radio Free Europe|date=7 December 2007}}{{cite web|title=The "Novy Chas" Newspaper Resumed Publication|url=http://www.kontrateksty.pl/files/news/2007061185838.html|work=Kontrateksty|accessdate=23 January 2014|date=25 May 2007}} The publisher is the [[Frantsishak Skaryna Belarusian Language Society]].{{cite web|title=Belarusian – the language of the élite|url=http://en.kulturaenter.pl/belarusian-the-language-of-the-elite-aleh-trusau-interview/2012/08/|work=Kultura Enter|accessdate=23 January 2014|author=Aleh Trusau|date=August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140123194200/http://en.kulturaenter.pl/belarusian-the-language-of-the-elite-aleh-trusau-interview/2012/08/|archivedate=23 January 2014|df=}} The society also publishes ''[[Nasha Slova]]'' newspaper and youth magazine ''[[Verasen]]''. ''Novy Chas'' which published weekly is headquartered in [[Minsk]]{{cite web|title=Committee to Protect Journalists’ Statement on Novy Chas’ Case|url=http://novychas2.wordpress.com/2007/12/18/committee-to-protect-journalists-statement-on-novy-chas-case/|work=Committee to Protect Journalists|accessdate=23 January 2014|date=17 December 2007}} and has an independent and liberal political leaning. In June 2009, ''Novy Chas'' is the recipient of the Zeit prize awarded by Zeit-Stiftung Ebelin und Gerd Bucerius, a German foundation.{{cite news|title=Belarusian Newspaper Novy Chas Wins Award of Germany’s Zeit Foundation|url=http://democraticbelarus.eu/news/belarusian-newspaper-novy-chas-wins-award-germany-s-zeit-foundation|accessdate=23 January 2014|work=Democratic Belarus|date=4 June 2009}}{{cite web|title=Free Press defenders receive awards at the Nobel Institute in Oslo|url=http://humanrightshouse.org/Articles/16573.html|work=Human Rights House|accessdate=23 January 2014|date=17 June 2011}} As of 2010 Alyaksey Karol was the editor-in-chief of the paper. ==Incidents== Shortly after its start ''Novy Chas'' was closed down and resumed publication on 25 May 2007. The paper was warned by the Belarus authorities at the end of 2007. In June 2010, the paper was also warned by the information ministry due to the absence of the [[editor in chief]]'s [[patronymic]] and the [[bar code]] from the imprint of the newspaper.{{cite news|title=Information Ministry Issues Warning to Newspaper Novy Chas|url=http://democraticbelarus.eu/news/information-ministry-issues-warning-newspaper-novy-chas|accessdate=23 January 2014|work=Democratic Belarus|date=14 June 2010}} In addition, it was barred from the state distribution network. ==See also== * [[List of newspapers in Belarus]] ==References== {{Reflist|33em}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Novy Chas}} [[Category:2007 establishments in Belarus]] [[Category:Publications established in 2007]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Belarus]] [[Category:Belarusian-language newspapers]] [[Category:Weekly newspapers]] [[Category:Media in Minsk]]

{{Other uses|Operation Moshe (disambiguation)}}
'''Operation Moses''' ({{lang-he-n|מִבְצָע מֹשֶׁה}}, ''Mivtza Moshe'') refers to the covert evacuation of [[Ethiopian Jew|Ethiopian Jews]] (known as the "[[Beta Israel]]" community or "Falashas")<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyofwar.org/articles/wars_moses.html |title=Operation Moses |publisher=Historyofwar.org |date= |accessdate=2013-08-31}}</ref> from [[Sudan]] during a civil war that caused a famine in 1984. Originally called ''Gur Aryeh Yehuda'' (“Cub of the Lion of Judah”) by Israelis, the [[United Jewish Appeal]] changed the name to “Operation Moses.”<ref>{{cite book|last=Lenhoff|first=Howard|title=Black Jews, Jews, and Other Heroes: How Grassroots Activism Led to the Rescue of the Ethiopian Jews|year=2007|publisher=Gefen Publishing House|isbn=978-9652293657|page=263}}</ref>
==History== The operation, named after the [[Bible|biblical]] figure [[Moses]], was a cooperative effort between the [[Israel Defense Forces]], the [[Central Intelligence Agency]], the United States embassy in [[Khartoum]], [[mercenary|mercenaries]], and [[Sudan]]ese state security forces.<ref>[http://www.iaej.co.il/newsite/content.asp?pageid=449&lang=en Aliyah through Sudan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206203622/http://www.iaej.co.il/newsite/content.asp?pageid=449&lang=en |date=2010-12-06 }}</ref> Years after the operation completed, it was revealed that Sudanese Muslims and secret police of Sudan also played a role in facilitating the mass migration of Ethiopian Jews out of Sudan.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lenhoff|first=Howard|title=Black Jews, Jews, and Other Heroes: How Grassroots Activism Led to the Rescue of the Ethiopian Jews|year=2007|publisher=Gefen Publishing House|isbn=978-9652293657|page=214}}</ref> Operation Moses was the brainchild of then Associate U.S. Coordinator for Refugee Affairs, Richard Krieger. After receiving accounts of the persecution of Ethiopian Jews in the refugee camps, Krieger came up with the idea of an airlift and met with Mossad and Sudanese representatives to facilitate the Operation.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bard|first1=Mitchell|last2=Lenhoff|first2=Howard|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Judaism/ejus.html|title=Ethiopian Jewry: America's Role in the Rescue of Ethiopian Jewry|work= Jewishvirtuallibrary.org|accessdate=24 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b79tAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=richard+krieger|title=Redemption Song|work=google.com|accessdate=24 May 2016}}</ref>
After a secret Israeli cabinet meeting in November 1984, the decision was made to go forward with Operation Moses.<ref>{{cite web|title=Today in History: Operation Moses|url=http://www.idfblog.com/2011/11/21/today-in-history-the-moshe-operation-bringing-thousand-of-jews-to-israel/|publisher=IDF}}</ref> Beginning November 21, 1984, it involved the air transport by [[Trans European Airways]] of some 8,000 Ethiopian Jews from Sudan via [[Brussels]] to [[Israel]], ending January 5, 1985.
Over those seven weeks, over 30 flights brought about 200 Ethiopian Jews at a time to Israel.<ref>{{cite web|last=Omer-Man|first=Michael|title=This week in History: Operation Moses begins|url=http://www.jpost.com/Features/InThespotlight/Article.aspx?id=195989|publisher=The Jerusalem Post}}</ref> [[Trans European Airways]] had flown out of Sudan previously with Muslims making the pilgrimage to Mecca, so using TEA was a logical solution for this semi-covert operation because it would not provoke questions from the airport authorities.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lenhoff|first=Howard|title=Black Jews, Jews, and Other Heroes: How Grassroots Activism Led to the Rescue of the Ethiopian Jews|year=2007|publisher=Gefen Publishing House|isbn=978-9652293657|page=236}}</ref> Before this operation, there were approximately as few as 250 Ethiopian immigrants in Israel.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Kaplan, Steven |author2=Salamon, Hagar |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Jews in Israel: Contemporary Social and Cultural Patterns|year=2004|publisher=Brandeis|isbn=978-1584653271|page=Chapter Five: Ethiopian Jews in Israel: A Part of the People or Apart from the People?}}</ref> Thousands of Beta Israel had fled Ethiopia on foot for refugee camps in Sudan, a journey which usually took anywhere from two weeks to a month.<ref>{{cite web|last=Ministry of Immigrant Absorption|title=Operation Moses – Aliyah of Ethiopian Jewry (1984)|url=http://www.moia.gov.il/English/FeelingIsrael/AboutIsrael/Pages/mivtzaMoshe.aspx}}</ref> It is estimated as many as 4,000 died during the trek, due to violence and illness along the way. Sudan secretly allowed Israel to evacuate the refugees. Two days after the airlifts began, Jewish journalists wrote about “the mass rescue of thousands of Ethiopian Jews.”<ref>{{cite book|last=Lenhoff|first=Howard|title=Black Jews, Jews, and Other Heroes: How Grassroots Activism Led to the Rescue of the Ethiopian Jews|year=2007|publisher=Gefen Publishing House|isbn=978-9652293657|page=264}}</ref>
Operation Moses ended on Friday, January 5, 1985, after Israeli Prime Minister [[Shimon Peres]] held a press conference confirming the airlift while asking people not to talk about it. Sudan killed the airlift moments after Peres stopped speaking, ending it prematurely as the news began to reach their Arab allies.<ref>{{cite web|title=Black Over White: Info on Ethiopian Jews|url=http://cjebaltimore.org}}</ref> Once the story broke in the media, Arab countries pressured Sudan to stop the airlift. Although thousands made it successfully to Israel, many children died in the camps or during the flight to Israel, and it was reported that their parents brought their bodies down from the aircraft with them.<ref>{{cite web|last=Jewish Chronicle|title=Operation Moses Suspended: January 5 1985: The world learns of the rescue of Ethiopian Jews|url=http://www.thejc.com/news/on-day/43249/on-day-operation-moses-suspended}}</ref> Some 1,000 Ethiopian Jews were left behind, approximately 500 of whom were evacuated later in the U.S.-led [[Operation Joshua]].<ref>{{cite book|author1=Kaplan, Steven |author2=Salamon, Hagar |lastauthoramp=yes |title=Jews in Israel: Contemporary Social and Cultural Patterns (Tauber Institute Series for the Study of European Jewry)|year=2004|publisher=Brandeis|isbn=978-1584653271|page=Chapter Five}}</ref> More than 1,000 so-called "orphans of circumstance" existed in Israel, children separated from their families still in Africa, until five years later [[Operation Solomon]] took 14,324 more Jews to Israel in 1991.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/Judaism/ejhist.html#operation1 |title=The History of Ethiopian Jews |publisher=Jewishvirtuallibrary.org |date= |accessdate=2013-08-31}}</ref> Operation Solomon in 1991 cost Israel $26 million to pay off the dictator-led government, while Operation Moses had been the least expensive of all rescue operations undertaken by Israel to aid Jews in other countries.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lenhoff|first=Howard|title=Black Jews, Jews, and Other Heroes:|year=2007|publisher=Gefen Publishing House|isbn=978-9652293657|page=214}}</ref>
==Cultural references== This operation was the subject of an Israeli-French film titled ''[[Live and Become]]'', directed by Romanian-born [[Radu Mihăileanu]]. The film centers on an Ethiopian child whose Christian mother passes him as a Jew so he can immigrate to Israel along with the Jews in order to escape the famine that is looming in Ethiopia. The film went on to win the 2005 award for Best Film at the [[Copenhagen International Film Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0388505/|title=Live and Become (2005)|date=1 February 2008|work=IMDb|accessdate=24 May 2016}}</ref>
In the book ''[[World War Z]]'' by Max Brooks, the evacuation of African Jews to Israel in response to the outbreak of the titular epidemic is referred to as Operation Moses II.
==See also== * [[Operation Mural]] 1961 in Morocco * [[Operation Yachin]] 1961–1964 in Morocco * [[Jewish Agency for Israel]] * [[Ethiopian Jews in Israel]]
{{Portal|1980s}}
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite web|title=Dugdale-Pointon, TDP. (1 April 2001), Operation Moses|url=http://www.historyofwar.org/articles/wars_moses.html|accessdate=2008-07-24}} * {{cite news|title=1985: Israel ends major Ethiopian rescue mission|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/january/5/newsid_4071000/4071661.stm|publisher=BBC|accessdate=2007-04-04 | date=1985-01-05 | location=London}} * {{cite news|author=Anastasia Toufexis|title=Israel Stormy Skies for a Refugee Airlift|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,956274-1,00.html|publisher=[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]|date=1985-01-21|accessdate=2007-04-04}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20040408162905/http://www.iaej.co.il/pages/history_operation_moses.htm Israel Association for Ethiopian Jews]
==Further reading== * Parfitt, Tudor (1985) Operation Moses: the untold story of the secret exodus of the Falasha Jews from Ethiopia. London : Weidenfeld and Nicolson. * Meiri, Baruch 2001, "The Dream Behind Bars: The Story of the Prisoners of Zion from Ethiopia", Gefen Publishing House. {{ISBN|965-229-221-4}} * Poskanzer, Alisa 2000, "Ethiopian Exodus", Gefen Publishing House. {{ISBN|965-229-217-6}} * Rosen, Ricki 2006, "Transformations: From Ethiopia to Israel", Gefen Publishing House. {{ISBN|965-229-377-6}} * Samuel, Naomi 1999, "The Moon is Bread", Gefen Publishing House. {{ISBN|965-229-212-5}} * Shimron, Gad 2007, "Mossad Exodus; The Daring Undercover Rescue of the Lost Jewish Tribe", Gefen Publishing House. {{ISBN|978-965-229-403-6}} * Yilma, Shmuel 1996, "From Falasha to Freedom: An Ethiopian Jew's Journey to Jerusalem", Gefen Publishing House. {{ISBN|965-229-169-2}} * {{citation | author= Viktor Ostrovsky|title= By Way of Deception| publisher =Stoddard Publishing |year = 1990}}

'''Pink Saturday''' is a [[street party]] held the Saturday night before [[San Francisco Pride]] ([[Gay]] [[Pride]] Day) in [[San Francisco]]'s [[The Castro|Castro]] district. It coincides with the annual [[Dyke March]] in San Francisco.<ref>{{cite web |author=Jay Barmann |url=http://sfist.com/2009/05/14/cops_looking_also_to_put_damper_on.php |title=Cops Looking Also to Put Damper On Pink Saturday |publisher=SFist |date=2009-05-14 |accessdate=2012-11-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324034720/http://sfist.com/2009/05/14/cops_looking_also_to_put_damper_on.php |archivedate=2012-03-24 |df= }}</ref>
Attendees are asked to donate money at the gate. Gate donations in 2008 were around $20,000.<ref>{{cite web|author=compiled by Cynthia Laird |url=http://ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=3992 |title=The Bay Area Reporter Online | News in brief: SJ Pride this weekend |publisher=Ebar.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>
In 2009, the event's estimated attendance was 100,000 people,<ref>{{cite web|last=Bajko |first=Matthew S. |url=http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=4721 |title=The Bay Area Reporter Online | Political Notebook: Sisters downscale Pride party |publisher=Ebar.com |date=2010-04-15 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref> and cost $150,000.<ref>{{cite web|last=Hemmelgarn |first=Seth |url=http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=4031 |title=The Bay Area Reporter Online | A hot LGBT Pride Parade |publisher=Ebar.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Bajko |first=Matthew S. |url=http://www.ebar.com/news/article.php?sec=news&article=4011 |title=The Bay Area Reporter Online | Changes afoot for SF Pride events |publisher=Ebar.com |date=2009-06-25 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>
== 2010 shooting == During the 2010 Pink Saturday, on June 26, 19-year-old Stephen Powell was killed after being shot four times in the chest. Two others were injured after being shot in the leg. A 20-year-old man named Ed Perkins was arrested in connection with the shooting. Perkins knew Powell, but did not know the two others. The shooting was not a [[hate crime]], occurred outside the actual Pink Saturday event area, and was reported as gang-related.<ref>[http://www.sfexaminer.com/local/Suspect-in-Pink-Saturday-shooting-identified-97329604.html ]{{dead link|date=November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2010/06/29/BATC1E686J.DTL&type=gaylesbian |title=Police identify suspected Castro shooter |publisher=SFGate |date=2010-06-29 |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/ci_15391289 |title=Teen killed at street party - San Jose Mercury News |publisher=Mercurynews.com |date= |accessdate=2012-11-24}}</ref>
==See also== * [[LGBT culture in San Francisco]]
